—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and I understand from it that he has stayed at hotels.
—What is your question?
—Order! Senator Vanstone, ask your supplementary question.
—I understand the Minister's answer to be—

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have now directed Senator Vanstone to ask the question and she has begun with a preamble. Senator Vanstone is in contempt of the Chair. She should be directed to get on with it and ask a supplementary question; not make a statement.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, it is a pretty clear matter. Will you please ask the supplementary question and not make a statement.

—Order! I cannot hear if there are too many interruptions from both sides of the chamber. I ask Senator Vanstone to ask the supplementary question.

—I understand the Minister's answer to be that on occasions he has stayed at such hotels with discounts. Will he provide to the Senate at the most convenient time to himself the details of the Hyatt hotels at which he has stayed at a significant discount and will he provide copies of those bills?

—I would not have them. In any event, every time a public servant, let alone a Minister, stays in a hotel he gets a discount. There are cards issued to get them discounts. I can recall Senator Alston complaining last year about a bill from the Hyatt. I got a refund from the Hyatt because at that stage I was charged a small suite rate for a larger suite or something; I do not recall. I do not even know what the percentage difference was, and I do not intend to run around spending the rest of my life trying to find out.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence in a position to confirm that the United Nations has formally requested further assistance by the Australian Defence Force to the military component of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia?

—The United Nations has formally requested Australia to provide urgently to the UN Transitional Authority in Cambodia a movement control unit of 30 personnel for a period of four months. The Government has agreed to meet this request. The provision of this group is a critical requirement which can be met without detriment to our own capability and at minimum cost. There are about 4,000 UNTAC military personnel already in Cambodia, and a major influx of as many as seven battalions and support staff from a wide range of countries is about to begin.

PARA.TAB: The UN requirement is a temporary measure to meet an urgent need which will also allow the United Nations to get a permanent movement organisation in place without jeopardising the implementation of the settlement plan. The component will comprise nine teams of three specialist movement officers plus a coordination element. They will be deployed widely within Cambodia at major sea and airport locations and in Bangkok. The movement control group will be drawn from the three services. It will be ready to move to Cambodia by the end of this week. Costs will be met from the $49m allocated for Australia's UNTAC contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the answer he gave yesterday to my question about the clandestine meeting that he has admitted he had in his car in 1986 with convicted criminal and standover man Joe Meissner, and in particular to the Minister's claim that its purpose was to inquire of Meissner what it was that he was prepared to sell to Mr Gary Sturgess of the then Opposition Leader's office for $100,000.
—I didn't say `sell'.

—The Minister can refer to Hansard if he wishes. I will repeat the last bit. I refer the Minister in particular to the Minister's claim that its purpose was to inquire of Meissner what it was that he was prepared to sell to Mr Gary Sturgess of the then Opposition Leader's office for $100,000. I ask the Minister: firstly, how did he know that Mr Meissner was negotiating to sell documents and photographs to Mr Sturgess for $100,000, when this information did not become public until the recent Meissner-Perger court case? Secondly, did the Minister or Mr Warren Anderson, who arranged the Minister's meeting with Mr Meissner and at whose home a subsequent meeting with Mr Meissner took place in 1986, provide any inducements to Mr Meissner sufficient to result in the documents and photographs that had been offered for sale to Mr Sturgess being withdrawn from sale?

—I would imagine that no-one would have wished to provide inducements which had anything to do with the photographs because they never existed. Ms Perger has made four statements about the `Love Boat'—two on oath and two on heroin. I take the view that we are better off looking at the ones on oath.

PARA.TAB: In respect of yesterday's statement, I said that there was $100,000 in a suitcase which was being offered to Mr Meissner to say something about me or my colleagues in the Labor Party. That is what I said yesterday, so I can repeat that now. As far as Senator Baume saying that knowledge of this $100,000 only became known in the Meissner court case, he has got to be joking.

The Sturgess performance in a Kings Cross coffee shop has been well known in Sydney for several years. Senator Baume does not want to know about it but, since he has given me the opportunity, I think he should be told. I think he should be given every detail.

What happened on this occasion was that the now Director of the Cabinet office in New South Wales, with the express approval of the shadow Attorney-General and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, got one hundred grand and put it in a suitcase. I do not know where he got the one hundred grand from. I would be fascinated to know. Perhaps Senator Baume can enlighten us on that. Where did it come from? The hundred grand was then taken to the office of a solicitor by the name of Barwick, a well-known name, one might say.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Liberal Party, too.

—Yes, a well-known name in the Liberal Party, as a matter of fact, as Senator Bolkus says. The money was put in a safe. It was at various times moved in and out of said safe, depending upon the meetings which Mr Sturgess was going to have. This now Director of the Cabinet office was sitting in a coffee shop in Kings Cross with one table between him and Meissner—he tried to claim later that there was no meeting with Meissner—and he had someone running between the tables, he said, to relay information.

PARA.TAB: I found it extraordinary when that story started doing the rounds in Sydney years ago and I thought it would not be a bad idea to find out to just what depths Sturgess and his colleagues might have gone. But, then again, I should have gotten the hint from the way Senator Baume has carried on here and from the way he slandered the Speaker yesterday; an apology for that should be forthcoming, and should be forthcoming now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his diversionary tactic. I remind him that Ms Perger had nothing to do with documents, and I ask him specifically about documents.
—Are you going to apologise?

—On the question of an apology, I withdrew the comment I made about the Speaker last night, which Senator Cook would be aware of if he had been here to listen. Nonetheless, if those opposite want to debate the issue, it reinforces the point that declarations of interest are nonsense because his were not declared. I ask the Minister to kindly answer the question I asked—and I will repeat it for his benefit. Will he provide me with any evidence whatsoever that is available and public that the events he claims took place took place?
—Events of what? Which events?

—Will he provide me with any evidence whatsoever that it was known that Mr Sturgess had offered $100,000 in 1986 when the Minister's meeting took place? Will he then answer the second part of the question, which asks: did not the Minister or Mr Warren Anderson—and I note he carefully avoided answering this part of the question—

—Order! The supplementary question is becoming too long. It is becoming too long also because of interjections.

—Was any inducement offered to Mr Meissner sufficient to result in the documents and photographs that had been offered for sale to Mr Sturgess being withdrawn from sale—and I stress the word `documents'—including one which allegedly was a handwritten note from Mr Speaker McLeay on how to forge records of the ALP's Enmore branch?

—I categorically deny the inducement—but I already have. This is the second time. In terms of documents, I can recall publicity about documents at the time—there was a great deal of it. I can remember a series of documents, which causes terrible embarrassment, that I had signed clearances for dead people to move from one branch to another, and these were supposed to be being offered for sale. What Senator Baume has probably conveniently forgotten is that I did a number of interviews at the time explaining that, in the Labor Party office, the General Secretary simply certifies that a branch secretary is sending a transfer. I am sure there were documents. There were probably lots of documents. They did not scare me one little bit. I said so at the time. I anxiously awaited their production; they were never produced.
—Nice people you associate with.

—I was not up in the coffee shop, but I can remember that at the very time that this was going on, the then Leader of the Opposition, amidst a great fanfare of publicity, said he was going to produce documents for the police commissioner. As a matter of fact, it was Mr Sturgess again who went up to produce the documents. What did he produce? Absolutely nothing, because for 10 years Senator Baume and his colleagues have been going on about this without one shred of evidence ever being produced, bar the word of Virginia Perger. That is the only thing they have ever had. They have never had a scrap of evidence, not one.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, Senator Baume should put up or shut up—produce one bit of evidence after 10 years. But he will do what he has always done—he will wait for another six months or year and ask another grubby question. That will not worry me at all, as it does not now.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you justify meetings with Meissner on that ground?

—As far as justification is concerned, in the words of Mr Sturgess in the court case, `It is just politics'. That is what Mr Sturgess said about the one hundred grand. Mr Sturgess went to see Mr Meissner and so did I. The difference was that Mr Sturgess went with $100,000 in his pocket and I went with nothing.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services inform the Senate as to the most recent indications of recovery in the housing sector in Australia? Are the trends at the present time likely to continue in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad to be able to inform Senator Maguire that yesterday's figures for dwelling approvals show beyond any doubt that there is a recovery in the housing sector. In fact, there was an increase of almost 7 per cent in March. These favourable results have been brought about by the achievement of the highest levels of affordability since September 1985.
—It has been dead for so long that it had to improve.
—Surely Senator Panizza would not be protesting at such good figures.
—I am not protesting. I said that it had to improve.

—Improvement in affordability has come about for two reasons. First, interest rates have fallen. Senator Panizza would know that we are now able to get mortgages at rates of about 9 per cent. Secondly, the median price of first homes has fallen. That must be very gratifying to those of us who wish to encourage young couples, in particular, to make their first home purchase. Home buyers in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth are benefiting, therefore, not just from falling interest rates but also from lower house prices. On a national basis, the median price of a first house fell from $118,700 in December to $114,200 in the March quarter. This is good news. But, of course, the Opposition has a policy which will only increase house prices.
—Why is that?

—The honourable senator has asked the question and I will answer it. The Parliament is now familiar with the fact that the Opposition would force up the cost of new houses by about $3,000 by imposing the GST on them. That is a very simple proposition. In addition, the Opposition would lift the cost of agents' and solicitors' fees by 15 per cent—that is, 15 per cent on the fee for the real estate agent and 15 per cent on the conveyancing fee for the lawyer. As I have said, that is added on to the impost of GST on the new houses. It is quite clear. What about the cost of furnishings and other additions to the house? The Senate can see how these would all add up. These price hikes would wipe out the gains made by home buyers over the last six months.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, we saw a new direction from the Opposition. The honourable member for Forrest, in his comment on the good news about the lift in approvals, could only bemoan the fact that builders were not able to increase prices because of the forces of competition. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is cause for concern that the increase in building approvals has largely been at the expense of builders' profits. Builders have had to cut their margins to the bone.

I would have thought that that is what micro-economic reform is all about—about lean industry competing to deliver maximum benefits to the consumers, to the public. Unfortunately, what we get from the Opposition is special pleading, in this case, for higher profits rather than for a leaner operation delivering good benefits to consumers.

PARA.TAB: Under this Government, housing will continue to be affordable; under the coalition, unfortunately, we would have higher prices for housing.

PARA.TAB: Before the Opposition voted against this Bill, it had these words last week from the Premier of Tasmania:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I have spoken to everyone I can from the Prime Minister to the Leader of the Opposition to say this legislation should be passed.

ANSWER.PARA: . . . when it comes to the crunch, they
seem ready to let down Tasmania by putting their federal party before their state.

What about the industry? As the Opposition was busily burying the Bill last night, circulating 17 amendments and not wanting to move them, the National Association of Forest Industries, the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania and the Tasmanian Government signed the document which urged, on the basis of a name change, monitoring and reviewing the legislation, enhanced intergovernmental agreement processes and the discussions about the supply of timber to the industry in a national forest strategy, the Opposition to support the legislation.

PARA.TAB: What did Mr Mark Addis, the principal industry spokesman, say about that? Speaking on ABC radio today, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: As far as I'm concerned, apart from the sterling efforts of the Minister for Resources, Alan Griffiths, Federal Parliamentarians ought to be hanging their heads in shame this morning, particularly the Federal Opposition who, when they had the opportunity, put petty political posturing and point scoring ahead of job creation and investment. Now I cannot put it any more simply than that.

The reasons were that they found it difficult to shift from their earlier positions, and their earlier position was that they wanted more than the Bill offered. As far as I am concerned, that doesn't wash because the Bill does offer something of substance, it does enable investment and job creation to get going. It signals to the international banking and finance communities—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Bill remains on the Notice Paper. I therefore ask you, under standing order 73(2), to what extent the Minister is able to anticipate further debate in the answer he is giving today.

—Mr President, in response to the point of order, it really does not matter what the Standing Orders specifically say. If Senator Hill's point of order is upheld, then unfortunately 80 per cent of the Opposition questions will be ruled out of order. No-one wants that. Senator Hill has simply intervened to stall the Minister's answer. He should be ruled out of order.
—There is no point of order.
—You have been going on for 10 minutes. Why didn't you take part in the debate?

—I was asked about the consequences of the debate, not who took part in the debate, and that is the answer Senator Macdonald is getting. If Senator Macdonald finds the answer unpalatable, he will resort to his mindless tactic of chattering, chattering, chattering, but not listening to the answer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interrupted me when I was making an important point about what Mr Addis, the Director of the Tasmanian Forest Industries Association, had to say. He said that the decision:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . signals to the international banking and financial communities, or it would have signalled that Australia was providing security for one of its major industries, it legitimises wood production in native forests and it sets in place scientific processes for decision making. Now all of that is very real, it is of great benefit. They weren't prepared to take that and say, `well, whatever else we want we'll work for in the future'. They said we want it all now or nothing, and in my view that's unforgivable.

The Tasmanian Minister had something to say about that too when he referred to an argument which was advanced here by, amongst others, Senator Archer, that the Bill did not guarantee a pulp mill in Tasmania. Mr Rundle, the Tasmanian Minister, responded to that with this comment:

The fundamental flaw in that argument that has been run by the coalition is that the only major company in Australia putting up their hand and saying they wanted a project, and that was North Broken Hill, said that the legislation was bankable. . .
Mr Rundle said that Tasmanian senators were ignoring the one player in Australia which had put its hand up.

PARA.TAB: I began my answer by saying that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, was going to Tasmania to try to explain the coalition's position on the actions which it took last night. Today Dr Hewson says:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no way the project would have started, in my view, before the next election.

What has that got to do with it, for somebody who is not a totally opportunistic politician? The lead times for any major projects like this are huge and the window of opportunity is not very great. So Dr Hewson is on record this morning as saying that the project would not have started before the next election. He has a fixation with the next election, and he ought to have. When he goes to Tasmania to explain the coalition position on this matter, he ought to have a fixation with the next election. He will have to do better in explaining this matter than he did with the GST, both in Tasmania and throughout the rest of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I cannot believe that it is the same man who was saying a little while ago that this project had to go ahead. Now he is saying that it would not have gone ahead until after the next election in any event. It is a disgraceful performance by the Opposition. It requires a lot of explanation and we will be making sure that the community gets it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications.
—Make it sensible.
—That is an appalling comment. How can I make it sufficiently simple for Senator Cook's benefit?
—Make it simple so that he can understand it.

—I will do my best. What was the purpose of the Minister's trip to Hong Kong from 27 December last year to 12 January this year? Since becoming a Minister, how many times has the Minister been to Hong Kong in either an official or private capacity? Will the Minister categorically deny that he has or has had any business interests or business dealings in Hong Kong since becoming a Minister either generally or specifically in the telecommunications area?

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I refer to standing order 73 (1), particularly parts (c), (d) and (g). The first part relates to inferences, the second relates to imputations and the third one concerns hypothetical matters. Standing order 73 is often broken; things would not work in this chamber if we adhered to it strictly. But if the Standing Orders are to have any significance at all they ought to be applied. Libel is not actionable if it is committed in this chamber. I would have thought that it is for that reason that our predecessors, and we ourselves, have adopted standing order 73, which appears in chapter 11.
—What about slander?

—That is not actionable either. It seems to me that the question that has been asked by Senator Alston cannot be looked at in isolation. Over the last series of days questions have been asked of the Minister for Transport and Communications which bring his character into severe question. I understand that, in answer to the last question, the Minister said there was not a shred of evidence about any of these matters, other than what Ms Perger said, and that her evidence was not to be trusted. We are getting to the position where the Minister is being asked a series of questions, all of which impugn his character.
—Order! Senator Cooney, you are making a speech.

—I conclude by saying that, if the Minister does answer the question, it is not accepted. If he does not answer the question, his silence is used against him. Mr President, it seems to me that the time has come when you have to apply strictly standing order 73 and rule these questions out of order.

—Order! I have heard Senator Cooney's point of order. If I upheld that point of order and applied it strictly, the same position would have applied in respect of Senator Ray's comments on the last point of order that was taken. Eighty per cent of the questions would be ruled out of order. I looked at the Hansard for last week when I was not here. I believe the Minister was asked a number of questions on matters that were not within his portfolio but probably went to his conduct as a Minister. I have allowed them on the basis that if the Minister does not want to answer them he does not have to.

—It is some time since the question was asked; I hope I can answer it. I was asked what the purpose was of my trip to Hong Kong on 27 December last year. I did something that I do not know whether many senators do; I went on holidays with my family. My wife and children and I went away.
—Whose shout?
—Order! Senator Alston, you will withdraw that imputation. I have asked for a similar interjection to be withdrawn in the past and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—A bit sensitive over there, are you?
—I say to Senator Macdonald that I do get very sensitive to that.
—I am talking to this lot, not to you.
—Order! Senator Macdonald!

—However, it should also be noted that I was not in Hong Kong for all of that period. In fact, while it did not cost the Government a cent, I went to China to sign a social security agreement between Australia and China. I did not charge the Government for any part of the trip because I was on holidays with my family. I was in China for seven or eight days of that period as a guest of the Chinese Government.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the question beggars the imagination. Firstly, whenever I have the opportunity, I break the trip to Europe and stop in Hong Kong because I like it; it is a great place. I do not like 24-hour trips. It is difficult to get off the plane and go straight to work, so I stop there. When I have the opportunity to stop, I do.

Since being sworn in as Minister for Transport and Communications, I have been to Hong Kong once, and that was on the last two days of my most recent trip. While there I discussed pay television with Star TV and had a meeting with Hutchinson Telecom as well. As far as the trip from 27 December to 12 January is concerned, even though I was on holidays, I did take the opportunity to look over the port facilities in Hong Kong, which I consider to be pretty spectacular. I am glad that I did because I think that there are lessons to be learnt from Hong Kong for ports in Australia, and I hope that we can adapt to some of them. So that is it.

As far as the other matter is concerned, I have no business interests in a private capacity of any kind in Hong Kong. I never have had, I do not have now and I do not expect to have any. Every time I go to Hong Kong, in this job in particular, there are plenty of things that I can talk about, but I have no private business there—none whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to direct this question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, who is now looking at me. Is the Minister aware that the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the IARC, a WHO agency, has recently classed heptachlor and chlordane as, first, animal carcinogens and, secondly, possible human carcinogens? Does the National Health and Medical Research Council acknowledge that the IARC is the most highly reputable and competent WHO authority in cancer research? In view of the IARC's classification of heptachlor and chlordane as possible human carcinogens, will the Minister ensure that the NHMRC will reassess its current position, which is that heptachlor and chlordane pose no carcinogenic risk to humans?

—It is quite evident that any matter to do with the possible carcinogenic risk to humans of various chemicals has to be treated with utmost seriousness. I would hope that the National Health and Medical Research Council would be in a position to acknowledge the worth of any classification made by the International Agency for Research on Cancer. I am not able to say whether the National Health and Medical Research Council regards as definitive, absolute and binding any decision made by that particular international agency, but I am sure that it would be taken into account and given due weight.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the National Health and Medical Research Council is asked by Senator Coulter to reassess its position in the light of some report made by the International Agency for Research on Cancer, I will certainly forward that part of the question to the National Health and Medical Research Council, courtesy of the Minister, and ask that a full assessment be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister also identify whether the NHMRC has already given an undertaking, before it has reviewed the IARC recent report, that heptachlor and chlordane will remain in use in Australia for a further period of five years.
—I will undertake to discover whether that is, in fact, its attitude.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister confirm that while being a Minister he has had the use of a London apartment and a Rolls Royce provided to him by businessman and stockbroker, Rene Rivkin? If he can, why has the Minister not shown this on the register of Ministers' interests, given that the value of the use of the apartment and car is obviously more than the relevant $100 figure and that, clearly, an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist in such gifts being provided to a Cabinet Minister by a wealthy businessman?
—I stayed in that apartment for one day in 1989. I checked with the office of the then Prime Minister as to whether or not I needed to declare it and, given that it was one day, the answer was no.
—A special arrangement with the Prime Minister.

—There is no special arrangement. One just checks; that is what one does. In terms of this last trip, I think I was in the apartment for three nights. I am not sure, but I think it was three nights. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to answer that section of the question relating to the motor vehicle. I also ask why, given that in 1988 the Minister declared a plane flight from Sydney to Canberra accompanied by Gough Whitlam, Ita Buttrose and Rene Rivkin, in Rivkin's aeroplane and he therefore regarded such gifts at that time as being required to be declared, he did not declare these other provisions.

—Actually, that is not a bad story. As a matter of fact, my free flight to Canberra occurred because I was Minister for Arts and I was asked to speak at a fundraising dinner for the National Gallery. I came down to do that with the Chairman of the Gallery and the Chairman of the fundraising organisation. However, I also checked on that occasion and I was advised to declare it because the rules on plane flights apparently, for whatever reason—and it escapes me completely—are fairly strict.I do not understand why because I do not really think that going on a flight down here to take part in a dinner to raise money for one of the organisations under my ministerial control would matter very much. I doubt very much whether the Australian people would be vitally interested in whether or not I flew with Australian Airlines or flew in a private plane. Nonetheless, I was advised to declare it, so I did.

PARA.TAB: I imagine that the advice would be that if my stay in the apartment was three nights, and I think it was, I should declare it. As far as the car is concerned, I used the car on this trip, so I will declare it as well. I do not know that it is that big a deal, given that it was only a couple of days, but I am quite happy to declare it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Southern Africa, including most of South Africa, is reportedly experiencing its worst drought this century and several countries in the region have already declared a state of disaster. What action is the international community, and Australia in particular, taking to help avert the unprecedented tragedy facing the peoples of this subcontinent?

—I thank the honourable senator for his well-timed question. The Australian Government has been closely monitoring the drought situation in southern Africa and is very deeply concerned at the plight of the people in this region. The drought is assuming alarming proportions. By all accounts its impact will be worse than the 1984 drought.

PARA.TAB: Countries in the region are experiencing severe water shortages and at least a 50 per cent failure rate in their maize crops; maize, of course, being the major food staple in the region. Many countries are in fact experiencing crop losses of 70 per cent to 90 per cent. Zimbabwe, one of the few countries in the region which usually produces a food surplus, has already declared a state of disaster.

Recent studies by UN organisations such as FAO and WFP and by the Office of US Foreign Disaster Assistance estimate that the region will require imports of 10 million to 12 million metric tonnes of maize—five times the imports required last year. Excluding South Africa, the cost of the needed corn and its transport will exceed $US2 billion. Much of this will need to be provided as food aid by donors because the countries affected have limited or no resources with which to pay for commercial imports. Millions of people in the region are already exposed to famine, and widespread deaths from starvation are inevitable unless international assistance is provided urgently and on a massive scale.

UN organisations will shortly be mounting a consolidated appeal to the international community. This will be aimed at donor governments and at non-government organisations. Together with member countries of the Southern African Development Coordination Conference—or SADCC—and USAID, the UN plans to organise a pledging conference which will attempt to bring the full dimension of this evolving crisis to the attention of the world community.

The Australian Government has decided to respond to this crisis by providing assistance valued at $12m. We have agreed to provide rice shipments to the value of almost $7m to Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe under existing commodity assistance programs, and shipping arrangements are already well advanced. In addition, we will provide a further $3.5m of rice through the world food program. We will also fund special programs of assistance through non-government organisations to the value of $1.5m.

Today I will be advising—since he is in the chamber I can advise him right now—the Zambian Foreign Minister, Mr Mwaanga, that $1.3m in immediate assistance will be provided to Zambia, with additional aid to follow consultation with the world food program. These are immediate and substantial responses. The Government will continue to monitor developments very closely and we will be considering the need for further assistance during the forthcoming financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Will the Minister explain why he intervened in the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal hearing into the granting of an FM radio licence for Lismore the day before the ABT was due to complete its second hearing into the matter? Why did the Minister request that the ABT look at the granting of a supplementary licence to radio station 2LM?

—At several meetings with the industry body, the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, I have indicated that I agree with the industry's basic push that the number of new licences that have occurred in the last few years, added to the recession, have meant very difficult times for radio in Australia. Anyone who looks at the figures around the nation realises that there are an enormous number of radio stations losing money. Consequently—I am not sure whether it was the day before; I would have to check the dates—I did ask that a supplementary licence be looked at as an alternative in Lismore.

PARA.TAB: The way the current Act is drafted, however, I would imagine that there is no possibility of a supplementary licence getting up. I wanted to see, though, what view the Tribunal might take of having it, because once the Australian Broadcasting Authority is up and running after 1 July—that is, of course, on the brave assumption that we will get the new Bill through here in the next few weeks—I think supplementary licences in the new Act will be much more common than they have been in the past. I hope that that is the case.

I fear for the economics of country radio in particular. If we were to open up some very small markets to second stations, we would find both of them going broke. I would like to avoid that. I think we ought to be postponing new licences until such time as the industry has some real economic health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer, but he has really evaded the main thrust of what I was asking, because after a four-year process of trying to grant this licence he intervened the day before the final hearing.
—What is the question?

—My question is this: is it true that the licensee of Radio 2LM, Richmond River Broadcasters, is controlled by Mr Bill Caralis? Is this person known to the Minister and, if so, what relationship exists between the Minister and Mr Caralis?

—This is getting worse, and I did not think it could. A representation was made to me by Mr Harry Woods on behalf of Mr Caralis. Mr Woods is the member for Page, having ripped that seat off the National Party at the last election. Yes, I have met Mr Caralis, I think once, and it was about 15 years ago.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is it correct that the Government intends to abolish the Medicare item numbers for urine testing of methadone patients, to cease supplying methadone syrup and to cap grants for patients requiring methadone? Is it also correct that no further funding will be provided for methadone patients requiring pathology from the private sector? Finally, if all this is correct, can the Minister advise the rationale behind this move? Is it to save money, or does the Government plan to replace all of these with some better program or some other program?

—I am unable to answer Senator Lees's questions in the detail that she requires at the moment, but I undertake to get an answer from the Minister as to the way in which the methadone programs around the country might be being affected by changes to payments in relation to Medicare item numbers, as the senator suggests. I believe it is important to recognise that under the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse and the Drug Offensive strategy there is a very clear realisation that if Australia is to deal with drug abuse, it must do so by a combination of means, including education, preventative programs and health and rehabilitation programs for those who are the victims of such abuse.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the last part of Senator Lees's question, I am quite sure that if this decision has been taken, it will be driven not by finance considerations but by considerations of the best sort of program that might be offered within the general strategy of dealing with drug abuse in Australia, which has as its goal harm minimisation.

I am sure that within that context, and given that goal, if the Government has decided, as the question suggests, that the methadone program might be modified, at least so far as government and taxpayer funded support is concerned, then it would be in relation to an alternative program or emphasis which would provide for the proper treatment of those who have become addicted, particularly to heroin.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs. Can the Minister explain, in the light of Treasurer Dawkins's exuberance over the zero inflation report in the midst of zero almost everything else, how the latest 22.8 per cent increase in bankruptcies in Australia for the March quarter of this year, compared with the March quarter last year, can be viewed as anything other than a tragic reflection of the failed economic policies of this Labor Government? Are the 43 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the first nine months of this financial year compared with the corresponding period of last year and the current prevailing high levels of unemployment a reflection on the economy and the fact that it is not yet climbing out of a recession, as the Government claims, but is still deeply embedded and entrenched in it?
—These questions about bankruptcies in Australia are asked in the course of every recession. We do have recessions from time to time.
—Not one that was planned though.

—The honourable senator refers to its being planned on the basis of the misinterpretation of a particular comment. The Liberal Party Government certainly did not plan its recession; it bungled into it and left this country with 10.5 per cent unemployment and 10.5 per cent inflation. Now, in an attempt to try to correct history, the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party has gone on television and said that inflation always comes down at the time of a recession. It did not come down at the time of the Liberal Government's recession.

PARA.TAB: These questions about bankruptcy rates are always asked. When the analysis is done, most of them are regarded as being the responsibility of bad or inadequate management. That does not mean that the recession has not been a considerable burden on a variety of small businesses.

In so far as Senator Boswell has tried to use this question as a peg to talk the economy down, let me say one or two things. The inflation rate in Australia is the envy of countries in the OECD and of countries in the Western world—also countries which have very substantial recessions. In terms of growth in the Australian economy, the average measure of GDP rose 0.1 per cent in the September quarter last year and 0.3 per cent in the December quarter.

The usual indicators of consumer confidence and so on are upwards. The housing sector is recovering. The ABS housing finance commitments rose 13.7 per cent in February. New home sales have risen. A private sector survey indicated that business activity has bottomed and that the worst is over. Expectations of business conditions over the next six months are improving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the unemployed.
—Senator Walters should be reminded that the unemployment figure is the lag statistic in terms of a recovery from any recession.
—And you planned it.

—I would not get excited with all these interjections now. The Opposition has put its alternative strategy to the people of Australia. They regard the Opposition out there as the sort of extended Manson family—a collection of Charlie Manson people who cannot sell anything, who cannot sell the GST package; it has gone down like a lead balloon. The Opposition has to rethink a number of issues. It is no good coming in here and interjecting selectively about bankruptcies or anything else.

—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation advise the Senate of the role of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in improving ship safety in relation to the recent loss at sea of several foreign bulk vessels trading with Australia?
—What a boring question! You have done this four times.

—Yes, it is boring; it is all good, clean stuff. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority is pursuing a range of initiatives aimed at improving both the standard and safety of shipping plying the Australian trade, particularly in the carriage of bulk cargoes. I have drawn to the attention of the Senate on previous occasions the extremely serious international problem of the loss of bulk carriers through structural failure; some 40 of these ships have been so affected in the last two years.

PARA.TAB: A report on one of those ships, the Manila Transporter, is being released today by the Marine Incident Investigation Unit of the Department of Transport and Communications. I commend it to honourable senators who are interested in this difficult international problem. It makes interesting reading. It highlights the role that AMSA plays in the inspection of lifesaving and safety equipment on board foreign ships visiting Australia.

In this case, the Manila Transporter developed a severe hull fracture in heavy seas and high winds while in the south Indian Ocean on a voyage carrying iron ore from Dampier to Port Talbot in Wales on 7 July last year. The crew had to abandon the ship and were rescued by another vessel. Despite later salvage attempts, the ship eventually sank about a month after its abandonment.

The investigation that was subsequently carried out found that AMSA's inspection of this ship's lifesaving equipment in Australia prior to its departure from Australia had led to the repair of a number of serious faults in that lifesaving equipment and was directly instrumental in the crew's safe evacuation from the ship.

AMSA is constantly reviewing and, as required, upgrading its ship inspection process. It has increased the number of ship surveyors, it has improved the inspection procedures and it has encouraged international cooperation in the sharing of information between countries in this region. The Manila Transporter report again illustrates the need for greatly improved standards in international shipping. It will no doubt provide more data for the current inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure into ship standards and safety. AMSA will be an active participant in that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Does the Minister maintain that the purchase of six vehicles in less than three years by Mr Burke when he was Ambassador to Ireland had any motive other than profit on resale? Are not diplomats warned against borrowings on unusual terms by the Department—to buy either cars or anything else? I remind him of the administration circular dated 10 December 1987 in which that was stated. Why did the guidelines in that circular not apply to Mr Burke?
—I believe I fully answered that question the last time Senator Knowles asked me it. I have nothing to add to this barrel-scraping excursion on which the Opposition has now embarked.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday, Senator Bell asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, concerning Tasmanian public nursing home beds. I have provided a copy of a further answer to Senator Bell. I wonder whether, with the leave of the Senate, it might be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Bell asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 4 May 1992:
1. Is it a fact that the Commonwealth pays a subsidy of S27.80 per patient per day with respect to Tasmanian public nursing home beds?
2. Is it also a fact that this figure was frozen in 1985? If so, why?

3. Is it also a fact that the Commonwealth pays a subsidy for Victorian nursing homes beds of S42.50 per patient per day? If this is the case, will the Minister explain why Tasmania is disadvantaged to the tune of three quarters of a million dollars for every hundred beds?

4. Would the Minister agree that this disparity in funding is causing severe financial hardship, with the result that institutions with aged care beds at Evandale and Wynyard have already been closed down or are currently under threat?
Yesterday I answered this question in part. I would like now to go on from what I said yesterday.

I indicated in my response to Senator Bell's question yesterday that the present freeze on Commonwealth funding for State Government nursing homes has been the subject of discussions between the Commonwealth and the States and has also been discussed between the Commonwealth and the Tasmanian Governments. In fact the Commonwealth was able to approve non-government nursing home funding in relation to the Cosgrove Park Nursing Home.

Most recently, a framework was put to State Health ministers by the Minister For Aged, Family and Health Services, seeking a resolution of this issue in the context of wider discussions on health and aged care. However, the States did not agree to go ahead on this basis.
The Government is now seeking other ways to progress this issue. As I said yesterday I am not going to forecast the outcome of further discussions.

Senator Bell also raised the case of two particular State hospitals yesterday, both of which include nursing home places funded by the Commonwealth as State Government nursing home places. These were the Wynyard and Evandale Hospitals. Evandale Hospital was also the subject last week of a question without notice which was answered by Senator the Honourable Peter Cook.
Evandale Hospital is being closed by the Tasmanian State Government and the nursing home beds from that facility are being relocated, at the State Government's request to another place.

Wynyard Hospital is a Public Hospital which includes some nursing home beds funded as State Government beds by the Commonwealth. The State Minister has announced the Government's intention to transfer the State Government beds from Wynyard to the privately run Yaraandoo Home For the Aged.

In both the Evandale and Wynward Hospital cases the decisions which are being taken are being taken by the State Government. Senator Bell's argument is that if there were no freeze on the level of Commonwealth benefit for State Government nursing homes the State Government would maintain nursing home beds at Wynyard and Evandale.

It is relevant in this context to note that nursing home care in a State Government nursing homes is a lot more expensive than in a non-government home. My advice is that the latest information available to the Commonwealth on the cost levels in Tasmanian Government nursing homes puts this cost at approximately $170 per resident per day. The difference between the frozen benefit level to State Government homes and the rate applied to non-government homes is overshadowed by this operating cost level. The Tasmanian Government could make considerable savings by addressing these high cost levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney on 5 May 1992 relating to the granting of an FM radio licence in Lismore.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer give by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) today has not properly addressed the many questions that must be raised about his action. The circumstances surrounding this issue will shed light on why the Minister has acted inappropriately.

PARA.TAB: In May 1988, applications were called for an FM licence in the Lismore area. Two applications were received from interested parties. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal conducted its hearing into the granting of the licence and, after waiting for a relevant decision from the Federal Court, the decision was handed down in December 1989 granting the licence to a syndicate named Northern NSW FM Pty Ltd. A legal challenge was then mounted asking for a re-hearing of the case. This was eventually granted.

Another legal challenge was mounted and eventually the re-hearing was set for 9 March 1992, four years after the applications were originally called for. At this meeting, the ABT received a request from radio station 2LM, the current AM licence holder in Lismore, to further delay the decision while it applied for a supplementary licence. This supplementary licence, if granted, would give 2LM control of both AM and FM bands in the Lismore area. This proposal comes four years after the original applications were called for.

Also at the ABT hearing it was revealed that Senator Richardson had written to the ABT, in this letter that I am holding, requesting that it consider the supplementary licence application in conjunction with the present hearing of the ABT. This, of course, would further delay the decision of the ABT.

At the time of Senator Richardson's letter, only a day before the hearing, the Minister had not received an application for the supplementary licence. It is completely unreasonable for the Minister to intervene to help a Johnny-come-lately at the last minute stage of the ABT proceedings. The process has been dragging on for four years and, just as the ABT hearing is about to conclude, the Minister intervenes on nothing more concrete than an assurance from an interested party that it would apply for a supplementary licence.

Fortunately, the ABT hearing continued as scheduled. However, a decision has still not been handed down by the ABT regarding the granting of the FM licence in Lismore. The ABT hearing concluded two months ago. As of this morning, the ABT had still not received any application for a supplementary licence. Therefore, the question immediately arises: what exactly is preventing the ABT from making its decision on this issue? The only answer can be the intervention of the Minister.

The question then arises: on what grounds does the Minister intervene? The law, as it stands, requires that the ABT grant an independent licence if the market can support such a licence. The ABT has already ruled that this is the case in the Lismore market. Therefore, if the ABT is to give 2LM a supplementary licence, it must award an independent licence as well. It would therefore not prejudice the 2LM case for a supplementary licence if the ABT were to award the independent licence now and stop this ridiculous delay.

It is also seriously questionable whether the ABT can actually hear a simultaneous hearing in this situation due to the sequence of events. For a simultaneous hearing to occur, an application for a supplementary licence must be lodged at the time of the notice of calling for applications for an independent licence or when an application for a supplementary licence is received the Minister must publish a notice calling for applications for an independent licence. Clearly, neither of these situations has occurred as the ABT still has no sign of the supplementary application. The Minister had not received the application by 6 March—almost four years after the original notice.

Thus, we do not have an adequate reason as to why Senator Richardson—the Machiavelli of Australian politics, as referred to in the Good Weekend magazine—has seen fit to request that the ABT delay its decision. These delays are costing the applicants a great deal in time, money and effort. The people of Lismore have been waiting for four years for an FM radio service, a technology that has been available to the rest of the world for 40 years. The applicants for the licence, the people of Lismore and, by association, the people of Australia deserve a detailed and adequate explanation of the Minister's actions and an immediate resolution of this matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
