TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 30 1991-92, Project Audit, Australian Taxation Office, Attendances and Absences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, I draw attention to the fact that the key findings of the audit were that absenteeism—that is, sick leave, special leave and short term leave without pay—accounted for about 6 per cent of the available staff working days, representing an annual salary cost of about $30m. This compares with an Australian industry work force average rate of only 4.5 per cent, dramatising the fact that staff savings and increased productivity could be achieved if the level of absenteeism was reduced to the Australian average, let alone to a better figure than that.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's report notes that the Australian Taxation Office has recognised the need to monitor overall absenteeism rates and identify, where possible, the causes of absenteeism. It further notes that the Australian Taxation Office had devolved attendance recording responsibilities to sectional management without identifying and documenting the risks and benefits of doing so. The Australian Tax Office has agreed to conduct a post-implementation review of the devolution of control over attendance recording.

The final basic finding of the report was that there was a need for improvement in management control over attendance and leave recording. Attendance records were subject to limited checking by sectional management and leave taken was not always properly recorded on staff leave records. As a result, it was found that staff absence entitlements could be exceeded.

There is always a risk that within the public bureaucracies, particularly when there is flexitime, there is scope for a considerable amount of absence, both formal and informal. The Australian Auditor-General has quite properly pointed to the extent to which formal absences in the Australian Taxation Office have exceeded the Australian average. Clearly as a result that is a matter of some concern.

I hope that the positive response by the Australian Taxation Office to the Auditor-General's report will lead to an improvement. I also hope that other incentives may encourage greater productivity within the public sector so that there will be an end to the time that we keep reading about worse than average absenteeism in this sector of the work force.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 31 1991-92, Project Audit, Australian Taxation Office, Use and Management of Consultants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Report No. 31, the Auditor-General's project report into the use and management of consultants by the Australian Taxation Office, is very damning. In 1990-91 the cost to the Tax Office of the consultancy services that it engaged was, according to the Auditor-General, a figure in excess of $8m. In fact, according to the table on page 2 of the report, the figure was $8.7m, which compares with a figure of only $5m the year before. So in the year 1990-91 the increase in the cost of consultancy services was a huge 74 per cent. I note that the findings of the report relate to issues other than the actual cost of the consultancy services. Nevertheless, I draw the Senate's attention to that very high cost of consultancy services engaged by the Australian Taxation Office and the enormous increase that occurred in 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: The more significant fact is the finding of the Australian National Audit Office that the Tax Office had not formally implemented administrative arrangements for the purchasing, managing, monitoring and reporting of consultancy services until December 1991. Indeed, in many instances it had not complied with the guidelines for the contracting of consultancy services.

In October 1988 the Government endorsed a range of purchasing reforms. Those reforms included the issuing of guidelines, by the authority of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) under finance regulation 42 on, amongst other things, best purchasing practices and techniques. The guidelines arising from the purchasing reforms included a guideline on the contracting for consultancy services. That was issued by the Department of Administrative Services in November 1990. That guideline outlines the required practices and responsibilities for planning, acquiring and managing consultancy services.

The time gap of three years and two months between the reforms announced by the Government in the area of purchasing until the Tax Office's compliance with them in December 1991 is a very concerning finding of the National Audit Office. Why on earth was a delay of that nature incurred? It is very important in terms of government purchasing practices generally—this applies perhaps even more so than in other areas of government purchasing—that there be seen to be transparency in the relationship between government and its suppliers. That applies particularly in the area of consultants, where we have seen so many examples over recent years of members of the public sector and members of government departments resigning on a Friday and starting work as a consultant on the Monday, often employed as a consultant by the very organisations from which they have resigned just the week before. I am not suggesting that that has happened to any considerable extent in the Taxation Office. That is not clear from the Audit Office report.

Transparency in the Government's use of consultants is of primary importance. The fact that there was a three-year delay between the issuing of these reforms by the Government and their recognition and adoption by the Australian Taxation Office is extraordinary and disturbing. When there is not transparency, there is always the opportunity for corruption, or for the less than efficient use of taxpayers' funds. If there is not open competition in the advertising for consultants and the appointment of consultants, there is obviously scope for government money to be spent in a less efficient way than it should be spent.

One of the key recommendations of the Audit Office is that the Australian Taxation Office, where practicable, follow competitive selection procedures for the engagement of consultancy services as outlined in the necessary directives, and that where this is not practicable the reasons and authority for not doing so should be properly documented. It was a matter of necessity that the Tax Office apparently agreed with that recommendation. It is a matter that we will be watching very closely to ensure that it follows the recommendation of the Audit Office.

The other aspect that concerns me—I would assume it would concern every taxpayer, particularly those taxpayers who have been subject to increasing vigilance by the Tax Office and the Taxation Commissioner in recent years—is that many taxpayers have been hounded and harassed by the Tax Office for the mildest of misdemeanours, if any, and in many cases for unconscious omissions or transgressions as a result of filling in the tax forms. The taxpayers of Australia have been hounded progressively over recent years, as has been discussed here many times, and often apparently in an unfair way. To find that the Tax Office, whilst pursuing that purity of approach in relation to taxpayers, has itself, in such an important area, for whatever reason, neglected to adopt the principles, procedures and reforms laid down by the Australian Government in relation to the engagement of consultants, smacks of hypocrisy and massive double standards. The Tax Office stands condemned for its failure in this area.

According to the Audit Office report, the Tax Office has responded positively to the recommendations, as outlined in the report, to improve the situation and to correct the gross deficiencies that have arisen.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it should!

—In response to that comment that the Tax Office has responded positively to the recommendations, I can say only that I should darn well hope so! In my view, it is a disgrace that there has been a need at all for this report and its recommendations and findings. I hope and expect—and I am sure that the Senate would expect it also—that the Taxation Office will view this report with the gravest concern and take immediate action to redress the serious faults that have been found in its handling of consultancy engagements. I am sure that other senators—including, I would imagine, Senator Bishop, who will follow me—can assure the Taxation Office that we will be closely scrutinising its activities in this and other areas from here on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Report No. 31 of the Auditor-General concerning the Australian Taxation Office is very timely in that it, along with the series of reports concerning the Australian Taxation Office, coincides with the inquiry being conducted by the Public Accounts Committee into the Australian Taxation Office. We have also had the opportunity of questioning the Australian Taxation Office during Estimates hearings, where we saw massive evidence that that Office has set one standard for taxpayers and left its own standards or its own housekeeping in the most appalling disorder. Indeed, Mr Boucher has gone on record as saying that many small businesses in particular fail to keep adequate records. In the Estimates Committee hearings we saw that the Australian Taxation Office itself had fallen far short of the mark in relation to anything like adequate record keeping.

PARA.TAB: In dealing with consultancies, this particular report draws two important matters to our attention. The first is the manner in which the Australian Taxation Office has gone about adhering to procurement guideline No. 13, issued in November 1990, and the second is the manner in which it adhered subsequently to the Commissioner's own directives, subject to that guideline, as to how the Taxation Office is to behave in the selection and employment of consultants. As my colleague Senator Short has outlined, adherence has been lacking. He drew particular attention to the fact that every year the Taxation Office—along with all government departments and agencies—is required to publish a list of the consultants it has employed, the tasks involved and how much they were paid. The worrying thing here is that, as the Auditor-General points out, only $5m worth of consultancy has been reported while $8m was in fact spent in the relevant period. Again, this is a blatant lack of proper record keeping.

In addition, it draws attention to the fact that the way in which the Government has gone about procuring goods and services since the change in the method of procurement, as set out by DAS, has led to a most unsatisfactory situation. We have seen more and more large contracts let where there has been no tender process and where one could say, perhaps unfairly in some cases, that there has been the selection of somebody's four first best friends or two first best friends—two people who cannot compete—and confidence in the method of procurement has been left wanting. Page 5 of the Auditor-General's report states:
The overriding objective of the reforms—

SPEECH.PARA: reforms brought about in the way procurement was to take place—
is to obtain value for money through the process of open and effective competition.

The problem with that concept is that it seems to be honoured more often in the breach than in the observance. Again and again we are seeing examples through committees of scrutiny where those necessary adjuncts, the process of open and effective competition, really seem not to have been relevant to the choice in the way a contract has been let. In relation to this report, the Australian Tax Office's annual report showed that, of 325 consultancies, 81 per cent had been engaged without either a selective process or being advertised publicly.

PARA.TAB: We had the most extraordinary example in the hearings of Estimates Committee A dealing with DITAC, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, where a contract to the value of $169,000 was awarded to one Mr Paul Batchelor, a former director of the Westmex Corporation, who did not even write a report in return for that $169,000. The Deputy Secretary to the Department, Dr Bell, regarded the contract as a shoe leather contract where there was no anticipation of a so-called glossy report being furnished at all. That was Dr Bell's testimony to the Estimates hearing. Subsequently I received further answers from the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that said that Mr Batchelor had, in fact, prepared a conceptual paper.

That is very interesting, but for $169,000 I think the taxpayer is entitled to expect more than a conceptual paper for a contract which was first described by Dr Bell as a shoe leather contract. Indeed, the result of that was that the same Mr Batchelor was made a director of a company on which the Secretary to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Chairman of the AIDC sit and was meant to administer that $1 billion fund which never eventuated. What curious machinations are going on in our method of procurement! I hold the Ministers responsible in these areas. The public servants are overseen under our system by the Ministers. They make the policy and they are responsible for ensuring that there is proper administration within their own departments.

Here we see in this Taxation Office report reams of evidence that the Taxation Office simply has not been complying with either the Government's requirements as to the way in which consultancies are administered or the internal directions of the Commissioner himself. What does that tell us? It tells us at the end of the day that the administration of the Department seems to have been largely left to its own purview and that the ministerial oversighting is itself lacking.

We have the curious examples of the way in which the Taxation Office chooses to exercise its powers against prominent individuals. One is with regard to the current unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, when he failed to lodge his tax return. All he got was a letter saying, `Tut, tut. Naughty boy. Please pop it in'. It is a bit like Senator Richardson. He forgets to declare that he was a director of a certain company when he is obliged to. It is selective morality, if you like.

On the other hand, in relation to Mr Phillip Smiles, who had a disagreement with the Commissioner of Taxation over the question of apportionment, which is a fairly common argument that the Commissioner has with other taxpayers, the Commissioner has chosen to prosecute Mr Smiles under the Crimes Act as distinct from the Tax Administration Act, which would be the normal way to proceed where a fine would ensue. The blatantly political way which has been chosen—to go under the Crimes Act and therefore imperil his seat in the Parliament—can only be seen to be what it is. It has been seen to be selectively moral in that it allows Mr Keating to get off scot-free, yet Mr Smiles is to be put into jeopardy.

Those are the only two examples we have on the record. Here we have the Auditor-General telling us in a series of reports, both these reports No. 30 and No. 31, that the manner in which the Taxation Office is conducting its own affairs is far from satisfactory. Indeed, going back to the Estimates hearings, we heard evidence from one Mr Butterfield, who was responsible for beginning an inquiry into the Taxation Office to see who had breached section 16 of the taxation legislation, which requires secrecy. When he was required to carry out an inquiry as to where that leaking of information had come from, he reported to the Estimates Committee that he had been advised that it was not the Tax Office and, therefore, he thought he was absolved, like Pontius Pilate, of any responsibility. But then he went on to tell us that he did not even bother to read the report. Here was a department that had a report, locked it up in a safe and nobody read it. That department thought it was absolved of all responsibility. It is not good enough.

That is better, I suppose, than the example of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce where, for $169,000, no report was even written. We were told subsequently—this is the curious shoe leather contract—that there were just a few odds and sods of papers. One does get a sense of great disquiet. It has always been said that there is no room in the public sector for corrupt behaviour, yet we heard, again in Estimates hearings, from the Tax Office that 35 tax officers were subject to fraud prosecutions. There is plenty of scope in an area where there is $8 billion worth of procurement annually.

I say it again: the responsibility must sheet back to the Ministers responsible. We must start asking the questions. If the administration of these departments is so bad and so sloppy, the Minister's head is the one that has to be asked for. More and more we will be looking very specifically at the way in which Ministers are oversighting their departments and taking responsibility for what is going on. They are sworn in as members of executive government to take that responsibility; they are paid in accordance with that responsibility; they answer here in Question Time, often in a facetious manner, without conveying information. Nonetheless, at the end of the day it is they who are responsible.

In this case it is the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) who is responsible. It is the Treasurer who must be held accountable for the appalling state that the Tax Office's own records are apparently in. I can only say to the Senate that, in taking note of this document, it will be but the start of a proper scrutiny and an accountability not just of the administration but also of the executive arm of government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Government recognises that nuclear science and technology can be used in many ways which are beneficial to Australia. It was specifically to encourage the safe, peaceful and beneficial use of nuclear science and technology that the Government, in 1987, legislated to revise the charter and change the name of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: That legislation established the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (Ansto). Its principal functions are to undertake research and development in relation to nuclear science and technology, the use of isotopic techniques and nuclear radiation for medicine, science, industry, commerce and agriculture, and the production and use of radioisotopes. Also, Ansto is required to encourage and facilitate the application and utilisation of the results of such research and development.
Radioactive Materials and Waste

Ansto has conditioned, stored and managed radioactive materials and wastes for many years both on its own account and on behalf of other parties. However, this activity was recently challenged when the Sutherland Shire Council took action in the NSW Land and Environment Court. It sought, inter alia, to restrain Ansto from transferring to the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories (LHRL) 17 cubic metres of radioactive waste from the St Marys site of Australian Defence Industries (ADI), and to require Ansto to remove from LHRL some 2,000 cubic metres of radioactively contaminated soil from the former CSIRO site at Fishermans Bend, Victoria. These wastes were to be stored at LHRL pending the construction of a national repository for radioactive wastes.

The issue before the Court was whether the storage was in accordance with the provisions of the NSW Environmental Planning and Assessment Act. Safety was conceded as not being an issue. The judge accepted that LHRL is presently the safest site in Australia for the storage of such material.

In his decision on 5 February 1992, Mr Justice Cripps found in favour of the Council. His ruling, inter alia, restrained Ansto from transferring the ADI wastes to LHRL and ordered Ansto to remove the CSIRO wastes within three years.
One effect of these orders is to prevent Ansto providing certain services essential for public health and safety.

These include, for example, bringing to LHRL for repair packages containing radioactive substances which have been damaged in handling at airports. Such services are obviously in the public interest. In the circumstances, the Government has decided that Ansto's powers in this area must be placed beyond doubt.

The amendments accord Ansto the function of conditioning, managing and storing radioactive materials and waste from its own activities or from companies in which it has a controlling interest. The function extends to other radioactive substances from persons who are specified in regulations, thereby allowing Parliamentary scrutiny where such cases arise.

The amendments respect the order of the NSW Land and Environment Court that Ansto must remove the CSIRO waste from Lucas Heights by 5 February 1995. In addition, the ADI waste cannot be moved to LHRL except by specific regulation.

The judgment of the NSW Land and Environment Court has focused attention more sharply on the need for a permanent repository for Australia's low level radioactive wastes. My colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has been actively seeking the co-operation of the State and Territory Governments in locating areas for investigation to identify a suitable site.

The Government has ordered a full investigation of the technical, legal and other issues concerning the conditioning, management and interim storage of the ADI and CSIRO wastes. A report will be prepared by December 1992 identifying all practicable options. These actions clearly demonstrate that the Government has no intention of allowing the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories to become, de facto, a national radioactive waste repository.
Commercial Activities

The Government decided some time ago that public research institutions such as Ansto should be encouraged to become more commercial in their orientation and activities. Ansto has made good progress in this direction. The proportion of non-Budget revenue in its total revenue reached 30 per cent in the 1990-91 financial year—two years ahead of schedule.

However, the Ansto Act constrains the extent to which Ansto can make further progress. The Act may not be sufficiently specific, for example, to provide for Ansto's development and operation of its Business and Technology Park.
These amendments will ensure that Ansto has a statement of functions which permits it to carry out fully the Government's intentions regarding the commercialisation of its activities.
Immunity from certain State and Territory Laws

The degree to which Ansto, a Commonwealth instrumentality situated in the State of New South Wales, is legally bound by NSW laws is a complex issue. The policy of successive Commonwealth Governments is that such instrumentalities are to operate consistently with all State laws where there is no existing, parallel, Commonwealth law and where those laws do not directly conflict with the existing Ansto Act.

However, advice has been received from the Attorney-General's Department that the Ansto Act does not provide that Ansto is a Commonwealth agent or emanation. Ansto may, therefore, be fully subject to the laws of the State of New South Wales.

The Commonwealth has never intended that Ansto should be fully subject to State laws. Indeed, this situation is unacceptable as it may impair Ansto's ability to carry out its functions properly and may even be prejudicial to safety.

Accordingly, Ansto is to be provided with immunity from certain classes of State and Territory laws. Similar clauses are included in the legislation which established ADI and the Civil Aviation Authority. On the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, the proposed amendment is to apply retrospectively.
Once again, the amendment respects the judgment of the NSW Land and Environment Court in that it contains a clause excluding the CSIRO waste from immunity after 4 February 1995.
Nuclear Safety Bureau

The Ansto Act established a Nuclear Safety Bureau which is responsible to the Minister for monitoring and reviewing the safety of any nuclear plant operated by the Organisation. The Ansto Board appoints the staff of the Bureau and may assign it other functions to perform.

In practice, the NSB has operated with complete independence of Ansto's management. However, the structure of the Act means that the independence of the NSB is open to question. The Government has decided, therefore, to amend the Act to ensure that the NSB is independent of Ansto de jure as well as de facto.

The new NSB will have the principal functions of monitoring and reviewing the safety of any nuclear plant owned or operated by Ansto, and of providing technical advice to the Commonwealth on the safety of nuclear plant and related matters. It will be funded directly by Parliamentary appropriation.
Administrative Matters

These Sections of the Bill tidy up a number of administrative matters. They deal with matters such as employment conditions for the Executive Director of Ansto, and the setting of a realistic maximum monetary level—$1,000,000—for contracts which Ansto can enter without Ministerial approval.
Financial Implications

The amendments have only minor financial implications. Additional costs in the order of $150,000 annually will be incurred on an on-going basis to cover added administration costs associated with separating the NSB from Ansto.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
