TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is proposing this Bill in response to a report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities dated November last year and called The Use Immunity Provisions in the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission. The Committee also reported on the rights of witnesses before investigations and hearings initiated by the Australian Securities Commission and the use which may be made of the evidence, both oral and documentary, gathered at such hearings.

PARA.TAB: In its report the Committee noted that in hearings under both the Australian Securities Commission law and the corporations law, the right to silence is removed. Section 597 (12) of the Corporations Act provides as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is not excused from answering a question. . . on the ground that the answer might tend to incriminate him or her but, where the person claims, before answering the question, that the answer might tend to incriminate him or her, neither the answer, nor any information, document or other thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person giving the answer, is admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings. . .
Section 68(3) of the Australian Securities Commission Act provides as follows:
Neither the statement, or the fact that the person has signed the record or produced the book, as the case may be, nor, in the case of the making of a

statement or the signing of a record, any information, document or other thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person making the statement or signing the record, as the case may be, is admissible in evidence against the person in:
(a)a criminal proceeding; or
(b)a proceeding for the imposition of a penalty;. . .

The indemnification provided by making the oral evidence—and in the case of section 68(3) of the ASC law the signing of the record and the production of a document—inadmissible in criminal proceedings is described as a use immunity. The person is also indemnified against the use of evidence gained indirectly from leads provided by answers to questions or documents produced to the investigators. This is what is described as derivative use immunity.

PARA.TAB: The ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions claim that this places an insurmountable obstacle in the way of successful criminal prosecutions. This is because, in the interests of preserving the assets of a company, or otherwise minimising the loss resulting from mismanagement or fraud, the ASC will seek to act quickly through civil actions in the first instance. The ASC is concerned that, by using its powers to compel evidence in order to seek civil remedies, it will be prevented from obtaining admissible evidence which could be used in subsequent criminal prosecutions. The ASC and the DPP provided to the Committee a number of cases where they had moved down the track of a broad investigation and had then come across instances where future potential criminal proceedings may be in order.

The ASC and the DPP have recommended to the Committee that both the use immunity and the derivative use immunity be removed from the corporations law and the ASC law, which is effectively a return to the provisions of the old Companies Code. The main arguments that have been put in favour of such abolition are, first, that to remove the derivative use immunity would not set a precedent; secondly, that public opinion would support the abolition of a derivative use immunity; and, thirdly, that derivative use immunity is anathema to the ASC's regulatory function.

The main arguments against abolition put to the Committee are, first, that the current legislation corresponds to the protection offered by the common law privilege against self-incrimination and that the privilege is a fundamental right which should not be withdrawn. Secondly, it is said that the ASC is exaggerating the difficulties it faces as a result of the immunities and that to increase its powers may encourage unfair investigative techniques. Thirdly, there is the argument that the ASC is misreading its role by placing undue emphasis on the pursuit of criminal prosecutions.

The common law privilege against self-incrimination is an ancient one. It has long been established as a principle that individuals who are facing criminal prosecution enjoy the right to remain silent. It extends to direct incrimination and indirect incrimination. When the privilege is set aside, as it is in the corporations law and the Australian Securities Commission law, it is because the legislature has made an assessment that the public interest to have access to information outweighs the private right of the individual to refuse to answer questions. There is usually a restriction on the uses to which that information can be put.

In the end the majority of the Committee came to the view that effective regulation of the corporate sector may include legislative provisions which vary the established common law rights available to the ordinary citizen. It has accepted the evidence of the ASC that the immunity applying to the production of documents and the derivative immunity applying to oral evidence curtail the ASC's investigatory powers to an extent that seriously limits its capacity to discharge the responsibilities placed upon it by the Parliament.

It recommended that section 597 (12) of the Corporations Act and section 68(3) of the ASC law be amended to remove the derivative use immunity provisions, and that section 68(3) also be amended to remove the use immunity with regard to the fact that a person has produced a document. The Committee also recommended that these amendments lapse after five years, unless their application is confirmed by the Parliament within that period. That is what we call a sunset clause. The Committee's final recommendation was that both laws be amended to clarify that neither the use immunity nor the derivative use immunity is available to corporations.

It is important to note that the Committee's views were not unanimous. There is a dissenting report to which I put my name and which was prepared by my colleague on the other side of the chamber Senator Cooney, and by my colleague in the other place Mr Frank Ford. The minority report prefers the view that the limitation of the indemnity to answers given—and then only so long as they do not relate to the identification of documents—puts the rights of individuals too much at risk. We, the dissenters, concluded that the law treats the right to silence as a matter of extremely high principle. The protection it provides against the power of the state should not be diminished, except in accordance with the principle of comparable standing, and a principle of that quality has not been advanced in this instance.

The Government has proposed this Bill to implement the recommendations of the majority of the Committee. It purports to abolish derivative use immunity under the ASC and corporations legislation on the grounds that such abolition would enhance the ability to secure convictions under the corporations law. It also abolishes use immunity for the production of books. This means that the fact books were produced can be used as incriminating evidence in criminal trials. The coalition takes the view that a distinction can be drawn between making statements to regulatory authorities and producing documents. We agree that there is no strong reason for the retention of the use immunity in relation to the production of documents. It is difficult to imagine that the ability to lead evidence that the accused produced certain documents will lead to abuse. Once such evidence is led, then the documents can speak for themselves.

The coalition also argues that the privilege against self-incrimination should be treated as a personal privilege and should not be available to bodies corporate. We support the provision in clause 8 of this Bill which makes this clear. However, for the reasons canvassed in the Committee's minority report and also covered in considerable depth by the shadow Minister for corporate law reform and consumer affairs in the other place, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the coalition does not support that part of the Bill which abolishes derivative use immunity in relation to non-voluntary, self-incriminating statements.

Briefly, the reasons for this are as follows: firstly, it has not been shown that derivative use immunity has prevented any prosecution. Indeed, in the evidence that the ASC and the DPP put before the Committee, they cited a number of cases, but in none of those cases could it be specifically shown that derivative use immunity had prevented any prosecution.

Secondly, the privilege against self-incrimination is an ancient one and should not be lightly diminished. Again, this was referred to in the report. The Committee gave it long and hard deliberation, as I am sure my colleague Senator Lewis will refer to later in this debate. On the evidence to the Committee, in my view—I am supported by the coalition—circumstances have not been made out to abolish this ancient privilege against self-incrimination.

Thirdly, the abolition would increase the powers of the Australian Securities Commission, which already has greater power than the police in the investigation of offences. The privilege against self-incrimination can be claimed by a person who is being questioned by the police about a criminal offence, but not when he or she is being questioned by investigators of the Australian Securities Commission.

Lastly, the notorious offenders of the 1980s will not be affected, as they will be prosecuted—if at all—under the legislation which was then in force. I will return to that matter a little later because I know it is of specific concern to my colleague Senator Spindler.

It was recognised by the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities in its report that use immunity and derivative use immunity are essential complements to the removal of access to the privilege by legislation, and thus we should be especially wary of further eroding this privilege.

There is obviously a need to strike a balance between the Australian Securities Commission's desire to secure convictions and the ancient privilege of self-incrimination. In the present circumstances the coalition has come to the view that the privilege against self-incrimination is far more important.

I foreshadow that I will be moving amendments on behalf of the Opposition to remove those provisions abolishing the derivative use immunity. In the event that our amendments are not going to receive the necessary support—and I am led to believe by Senator Spindler that they will not—we will vote against the Bill at the second reading.

There were some other matters which I wanted to bring to the attention of the Senate in relation to the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities, which specifically, I thought, would be of interest to Senator Spindler, who I know has almost an unhealthy blood lust for trying to get the corporate crooks of the 1980s put behind bars.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very worthy effort.

—Some of those people are probably my constituents in Western Australia. One of the arguments of the ASC, the DPP and, in the end, the majority of the Committee which Senator Lewis, Senator Spindler and I have the pleasure of being on was this argument of the public interest outweighing the rights of the individual when it comes to the privilege against self-incrimination. The public interest is the argument that we have to deal with. As we have said many times in this debate, we have to create a balance with the public interest, create some integrity in our securities markets, create public confidence in our corporations and securities environment and, on the other hand, protect the privileges and rights—and very fundamental rights, in my view—of the individual.

PARA.TAB: In some evidence that was provided by Mr Santow, I think it was, to the Committee, he made a specific point in relation to the immunity which is provided at royal commissions versus the immunity that is provided under the ASC investigations. Mr Santow said, referring to the Sorby case:

I do not believe Sorby's case, which really was dealing with royal commissions, is necessarily apposite in this context. Royal commissions are not ASC investigations. They are designed in the public interest to find out the facts about a matter . . . I do not think it flows automatically from the fact that the High Court said that should not be used in criminal proceedings that the same public interest issues are at stake when the ASC. . . gets information under compulsion.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Senate, and particularly to Senator Spindler, that it is very hard to argue, on the one hand, that the public interest is preserved by taking away people's rights in relation to evidence before the ASC and, on the other hand, to claim that there is some higher public interest in relation to the proceedings of a royal commission. That is a point that perhaps Senator Spindler should consider. I do not deny that there should be a balance—I know Mr Santow's evidence was quite convincing for the Committee; I am sure that it influenced Senator Spindler—but he is really using the public interest on the one hand to support his argument and on the other hand to knock it down.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to raise in relation to the blood lust for putting in gaol corporate offenders from the 1980s and what that actually will achieve is the difference that we draw between the privilege that a blue collar criminal or even a capital criminal—a murderer or a rapist—receives in front of a court compared with a corporate criminal, a white collar criminal. There will be no equality for this privilege if we pass this Bill because the rapists, the murderers—the sorts of people who are going around needlessly bashing up people in the streets of Los Angeles at the moment—will receive a greater privilege than those people who are suspected of conducting a corporate crime. I have a quotation here to support my view. It comes from the Law Society of New South Wales. Mr Ehrlich, who also gave evidence before our Committee, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . equality before the law demands that crime of whatever nature, whether so-called `blue collar' or `white collar' should be subject to the application of egalitarian principles and procedures of investigation and prosecution and to the like preservation of the freedom of the individual from possible abuse of power in seeking to protect the public interest.
I think that is a very important principle. It is the principle supported by Senator Cooney as a minority reporter and supported by the Opposition in relation to this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Mr Santow, on the opposite side of the ledger, made a point in relation to the Guinness case in the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom has some very intrusive investigation powers and does not offer the people whom it is investigating any immunities from use of derivative evidence. Of the Guinness case, Mr Santow said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what it brought home to people—and it is affecting corporate behaviour—is that it is not just a matter of putting the money back; people actually went to gaol. People like you and me in blue suits and nice shirts went to gaol.

I was not there on that day, but I am sure that Senator Spindler had a big smile on his face when Mr Santow said that. Senator Spindler probably said, `This is my kind of guy'. That reflects the blood lust.

PARA.TAB: It brings us to the issue of the difference between civil remedies in relation to corporate law and criminal remedies. One of the policy aspects that the Senate and the Parliament should be dealing with is to what extent we expect the Australian Securities Commission to be a police force, to be a sort of corporate gestapo, going on fishing expeditions, looking into companies and trying to get criminal prosecutions. The Commission should be going about its business seeking civil remedies where possible, ensuring that there is a fair and open environment for corporate practices, that there is an ethical basis and that there is a very clear understanding in both the corporate world itself and the community at large of what is expected of directors, managing directors and corporations. There should also be a clear understanding of the remedies when they cross the line.

The last point I move to concerns the consequences of our action here today. One of the biggest advantages of having an immunity—of being able to compel evidence on the one hand, but being able to offset that reduction in the privilege against self-incrimination on the other—is that we can get much greater cooperation from the witnesses that we are investigating. If the witness knows that whatever he says cannot be used in evidence in criminal prosecutions, one would naturally expect that that witness would be far more cooperative with the investigation, and the longer term aims and objectives of the Australian Securities Commission would, of course, be enhanced.
Mr Ehrlich, again from the Law Institute of Victoria, made this point better than I am able to when, commenting upon what happens if the immunities are removed, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Such a position would lead to a situation in which the corporate regulatory mechanism would discourage witnesses from providing frank and full disclosure where the witness might be subject to criminal sanction. This would grossly undermine the objective of corporate regulation in getting to the bottom of corporate transactions so as to enable shareholders and creditors to use the information obtained in civil actions for damages or other civil remedies.

That makes the point very well about the role of the Australian Securities Commission. Should it be a sort of corporate Gestapo trying to lock up blue-suited, nice-shirted business people who ran amuck in the 1980s? Or should it be trying to create a corporate environment, seeking civil remedies and looking after the interests of the shareholders as opposed to, I guess, the natural blood lust that comes from wanting to lock up some of these corporate transgressors from the 1980s?

PARA.TAB: Of course, from a political point of view—and I would not even impute these motives to Senator Spindler or to the Attorney-General, Michael Duffy—having a few corporate crooks from the 1980s put behind bars would show the people of Australia that the move from the old cooperative scheme to the new centralised Australian Securities Commission scheme has been a success.

Regardless of all the other issues that people like Senator Spindler, myself and the members of the Joint Statutory Committee have been exposed to over the last few months during which our Committee has been in existence; and regardless of all the complicated issues relating to getting the corporate framework right in Australia—directors' duties, insolvencies and all the other issues that we are contending with—the success or failure of this new scheme in the mind of the public and in the politics of Australia will, of course, have been achieved with a couple of lynchings. I think that is really part of the political motivation behind what is being done.

I conclude by again referring to Henry Bosch, the former head of the National Companies and Securities Commission, who addressed a National Institute of Accountants lunch, on Friday I think it was, in Adelaide. Mr Bosch was soliloquising about what will happen in Australia when the next boom comes—and we all look forward to that arriving. He was worried, having seen what happened in the 1980s and having seen its aftermath—and I am reading Mr Bosch's mind at the moment, which I am sure a lot of people tried to do in the 1980s—that, with all the new regulatory framework, with the Australian Securities Commission and all its resources, the secret to getting it right in Australia is ensuring that there is a responsibility felt throughout the community.

Mr Bosch made the point that, for every corporate transgressor or high flier who appears in the Financial Review every day or on the front page of the Australian playing tennis, flying on jets or driving in Rolls Royces, many of whom were Western Australians, there are thousands and thousands of people in the professions—lawyers, accountants and auditors—who followed in their trail. He was appealing to the members of his audience to ensure that their house is in order and to ensure that they felt the sense of their role in rebuilding the corporate climate and the commercial climate in Australia.

Indeed, without their cooperation and without the belief in the ethics and the efficacy of all of the players in the corporate world, it does not matter how many millions of dollars we give to the Australian Securities Commission, it does not matter how hard nosed the head of the Australian Securities Commission is—be it a Henry Bosch, a Tony Hartnell or whoever replaces Tony Hartnell—we will not achieve the results that we all desire across both sides of this Parliament in rebuilding the integrity in Australia's commercial sector and security sector.
Mr Bosch said something which did not refer to the point I am making, but I shall use some licence here. When talking about the next boom, or the next period of rapid corporate activity, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There would be a need for new knowledge, skills and greater flexibility but there would be temptations to cut corners and to compromise principles in the fight for survival.

The coalition sees that getting rid of the privilege—getting rid of the derivative use immunity, and the use immunity as contained in the use immunity provisions of this legislation—is compromising a very important principle for what I see as a relatively short term political objective. Therefore, the Opposition will be moving the amendments I have foreshadowed. In the event that those amendments are not supported—and I still hold out hope that Senator Spindler has been convinced by my wise words, but in the event that he does not and the Senate does not support those amendments—we will be opposing this at the second reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to remove certain immunities available to witnesses under section 68 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 and section 597 of the Corporations Act 1989. Investigations under the Corporations Act are conducted before a court at the request of the ASC, and investigations under the ASC Act are conducted by the ASC itself.

PARA.TAB: Under common law it is a well established principle that the prosecution must prove guilt and that the accused cannot be forced to provide information which incriminates him or her. This immunity against self-incrimination is expressly excluded by the Corporations and the Australian Securities Commission legislation. There are a number of reasons for that. One of those reasons is that the immediate victim, the company, is a legal construct, and there often is no human victim with direct and immediate knowledge of the circumstances involved. As a result, the prosecution is compelled to rely on the perpetrator for evidence of the misdeed. A second reason is that very frequently the complexity of the documentary evidence means that it needs to be explained by the person who knows it or who, indeed, has generated it.

The need for this legislation now before the Senate arises from the fact that both the ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions—the agencies responsible respectively for investigating and prosecuting corporate fraud—have been experiencing serious problems in bringing effective prosecutions. Far from exhibiting blood lust, as my colleague Senator Campbell is trying to impute to me, I believe that respect for the law is based on the fact that people cannot flout it and get away with it. I rather fear that the position that Senator Campbell adopts might in some way be coloured by the fact that, as he says, some of the targets of that legislation are amongst his constituents. We should consider that if we can allow such laws which are designed to protect the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I know that this debate is taking place in a relatively friendly atmosphere, but Senator Spindler has not only imputed but specifically implied that I have taken the position that I have on this Bill because a number of my constituents happen to be corporate high-fliers in Western Australia. That is a grave imputation. I think Senator Spindler should withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure Senator Campbell that what I said was not intended to be an imputation on his character in any way whatsoever. In fact, what I did was repeat some of his own words. I believe that Senator Campbell has no grounds for complaint.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, we cannot allow laws which are designed to protect investors—many of them people who have placed their life savings at risk—to be thrown to the wolves, as it were, without ensuring that we have legislation in place which can ensure that these people, as a deterrent, are brought to justice. Of course, the main concern that we have is to protect those people. We are looking not only at the past and the misdeeds perpetrated by our corporate cowboys in the roaring eighties in Australia, misdeeds which rival anything that happened elsewhere in the world, but also to the future to ensure that people can entrust their savings to financial institutions, to corporations, without being scared, every day and every night, that they will lose their life savings.

There is perhaps another very simple point that should be made in rebutting some of the things which Senator Campbell has said, and that is simply that justice must be done and must be seen to be done. Our society cannot function if we allow people to flout not only the laws of the country but also the rules of simple, ethical behaviour. Where people clearly demonstrate that they are not capable of following simple, ethical rules of behaviour, the law must step in. We must ensure that the law is enforced. Otherwise it becomes a joke.

The need for this legislation arises from the fact that both the ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions—the agencies responsible for investigating and prosecuting corporate fraud—have been experiencing serious problems in their work. The immunities available to witnesses under section 68 of the ASC Act and section 597 of the Corporations Act have the combined effect of precluding the use of certain evidence against a person in criminal proceedings and proceedings for the imposition of a penalty. Such evidence includes a person's self-incriminatory oral statements, the signing of a record and the production of a book; for instance, a diary. This is described as use immunity. It also includes any information, document or other thing obtained as a result of such statements or actions. This is described as derivative use immunity. Section 68 of the ASC Act currently provides for use immunity and derivative use immunity with respect to oral statements, signing of records and the production of a book. Section 597 of the Corporations Act currently provides for use immunity with respect to oral statements and derivative use immunity with respect to oral statements, signing of records and the production of a book.

An example of derivative use immunity will occur where a person who has produced financial records of a company refuses to answer, under examination, questions as to whether he or she authorised journal entries in the financial records and whether he or she signed certain correspondence, and, indeed, any other matters arising out of that correspondence or those books. The immunity claimed in these circumstances is one for non-disclosure of evidence derived from records already properly admitted into evidence. Both the ASC and the DPP have made submissions before the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, of which Senator Cooney, Senator Campbell and I are all members. They outlined the problems associated with derivative use immunity, as in the above example that I have cited. The ASC has submitted evidence that the immunity applying to the production of documents was, indeed, curtailing quite severely its investigatory powers and its ability to obtain evidence leading to successful prosecutions.

In November 1991, the Joint Committee released its report entitled Use Immunity Provisions of the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission Law. The report recommended that section 597 of the Corporations Act and section 68 of the ASC Act be amended to remove the derivative use immunity provisions and that section 68 of the ASC Act also be amended to remove the use immunity with regard to the fact that a person has produced a book, for instance, a diary.

In addition, the Joint Committee recommended that the Corporations Act and the ASC Act be amended to ensure that neither the use immunity nor derivative use immunity be available to corporations and that the proposed amendments lapse after five years unless the Parliament confirms their application within that period. This Bill adopts the recommendations of the Joint Committee with the exception of the recommendation that there be a five-year sunset clause on the amendments. I will return to this point later.

The main ground of opposition to the recommendations of the Joint Committee is that the current legislation corresponds to the protection offered by the common law privilege against self-incrimination in Australia and that the privilege is a fundamental right which should not be withdrawn. This is the central argument in the dissenting report by Senator Barney Cooney and Mr Frank Ford, which is now supported by Senator Ian Campbell.

The Australian Democrats are mindful of the strength of the arguments contained in the dissenting report and are extremely concerned that no inroads should be permitted on the rights of citizens before a court. However, in this case, it is wrong to say that the privilege against self-incrimination is being withdrawn. Use immunity remains in full force for oral statements and signing of records under the ASC Act and for oral statements under the Corporations Act. It will not be available in the case of information, including the contents of a book, derived from other evidence obtained legally under valid investigation processes.

There has been a substantial volume of evidence in this area which shows that investigators in the corporate law area find grave difficulties in situations such as where a person who has produced financial records of a company refuses to answer under examination questions as to whether he or she signed certain correspondence. The need to protect small investors and their savings conflicts with the present right of corporate officials to refuse such answers. As Senator Campbell quite rightly said, we need to strike a balance.

One major difficulty is clearly that a person under investigation might deliberately introduce information on matters which may be relatively unrelated but for which he or she may want to claim immunity later on. I do not believe that we can countenance legislation which provides that loophole to people who have designs on flouting the law as it stands.

On balance, the Australian Democrats believe that our corporate world does need cleaning up and that we must protect the rights and interests of people who entrust their savings to entrepreneurs and financial institutions. In doing so, we must be conscious of the antics of our corporate cowboys in the 1980s who have diverted millions of dollars of savings entrusted to their care and who have used every trick in the book, including the use of derivative use and use immunities, to keep their ill-gotten gains and to try to escape liability.

The amendments to be made by this Bill are as follows: to remove the derivative use immunity and use immunity in respect of the production of a book currently available to a person under section 68 of the ASC Act 1989; and to remove the derivative use immunity in respect of the making of all statements and the signing of records. As a result, the privilege against self-incrimination will only apply to the use immunity currently available in relation to oral statements and the signing of records. The privilege will be available only to natural persons since corporations are specifically excluded.

Secondly, the amendments seek to remove the derivative use immunity currently available to a person under section 597 of the Corporations Act 1989. As a result, the privilege against self-incrimination will apply only to the use immunity currently available in relation to oral statements. The privilege will be available only to natural persons. Once again, corporations are specifically excluded.

As I have said before, the Democrats are very mindful of the conflicting principles involved and will be moving an amendment to ensure that the operation of this legislation is reviewed within five years of its commencement. There is currently no provision in the legislation for a review to check whether these provisions will turn out to be an excessive infringement of the common law privilege against self-incrimination.

The Joint Committee proposed a five-year sunset clause which the Government rejected on practical grounds—namely, that serious problems could arise in the prosecution of matters which may have been under investigation for some time and which may still be in process when the five-year limit approaches. The Government gave an undertaking that the operation of the amendments is to be reviewed within five years. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) gave a personal commitment to hold an interim review after 12 months. However, I and the Democrats as a party believe that this is an extremely important matter. Clearly, it is being decided on a balance of conflicting principles. We believe that it is incumbent upon us to have a provision in the legislation to ensure that this review is carried out within the five-year period.

Obviously there is concern about a review of these amendments taking place. The proposal put forward by the Democrats would be an effective alternative in light of all the surrounding circumstances. The proposed amendment requires the Minister to cause a person who, in his opinion, is suitably qualified and appropriate to conduct a review into the operation of the amendments within a five-year period and to cause copies of the review to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of receiving the review. Subject to this amendment, the Australian Democrats will be supporting this legislation for the reasons I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in the interesting position of joining Senator Campbell and Mr Frank Ford, the honourable member for Dunkley in the other place, in my remarks on the dissenting report included in the report entitled Use Immunity Provisions in the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission Law. I thought it was a very worthwhile dissenting report, full of integrity and—
—And learned.

—And learned; I thank Senator Lewis. I voted with the Party against the dissenting report that I put in.Since I wrote that report, I have gone along the road to Damascus, as it were, and been converted. Indeed, if I took that position, I would have the support of such eminent judges as His Honour Mr Justice Ken Marks of the Supreme Court of Victoria. In a very learned article in the Law Institute Journal of April 1984, he said the following:

PARA.TAB: It would have been consonant with the law—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the common law—

as it evolved after the Restoration for the judges to have advised, and the practice followed, that an accused be warned merely that he could not be compelled to answer questions but that his refusal might be used against him at his trial.

PARA.TAB: That is what should have happened and what should be the practice, save that a suspect should be only subject to adverse inference from silence if he has been given a choice to answer questions in the presence of an independent observer. A suspect should be entitled to ensure that what he says is accurately recorded and to require an environment which maximises his ability to do himself justice by what he says.

SPEECH.PARA: The modern manifestation of what His Honour says there is the videoing of interviews with the police.

PARA.TAB: I would like to be able to say that I have been convinced by His Honour Mr Justice Marks, but I have not been. Mr Justice Marks, learned as he is, is not right in what he has advocated there. I prefer the arguments of the then Director of Public Prosecutions of Victoria, Mr John Coldrey, who in the Anglo-American Law Review of 1991 at page 51 wrote an article entitled, `The Right to Silence: Should it be Curtailed or Abolished?'. He clearly said that it should not.

Again, I agree with the sentiments of Mr Justice Vincent of the Supreme Court of Victoria. Mr John Coldrey has now become Mr Justice Coldrey of the Supreme Court, having joined Mr Justice Vincent on that eminent bench. Mr Justice Vincent and Mr Justice Coldrey take the same approach. I confess that I find their approach compelling. In supporting this Bill as it becomes law, I have to go back to the fact that I am a member of a party which takes a particular approach on this and, having put my view in the proper forums in that party, I shall certainly support what it does. After all, that is how I came to be here. So that will be my approach on this occasion. I found the comments of Senator Campbell quite compelling. I also take into account what Senator Spindler has said.

As has been said by both speakers before me, the issue is one of balance. The matter is well put by Mr Justice Stephen and Mr Justice Aickin of the High Court in the case of Bunning v Cross. Their decision was handed down in Sydney on 14 June 1978 but, as Senator Campbell will be interested to know, the case was heard in Perth on 14 September 1977. They said this:

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand there is the public need to bring to conviction those who commit criminal offences. On the other hand is the public interest in the protection of the individual from unlawful and unfair treatment. Convictions obtained by the aid of unlawful or unfair acts may be obtained at too high a price.

The fact that there is criminality in the corporate world is beside the point. There is criminality no matter where we look. Even in that state which should be the state of greatest bliss, matrimony—and in my case it is the state of greatest bliss—there is often some sort of dislocation between the partners. Domestic assaults take place and at times spill over into murder.

PARA.TAB: The fact that there is criminality in marriage does not mean that we should take away the rights of everybody who commits such a crime. In fact, we do not. When a husband kills a wife or a wife kills a husband, or when they do damage to each other, those people have all the rights that the common law gives. They have the right not to incriminate themselves and the right of immunity against the use of whatever statements they make. As a consequence, they have the right of immunity against anything that is derived from the use of their statements. We tread on unhappy ground when we start curtailing those rights.Each case has to be looked at on its merits. I think Senator Lewis will agree that some very eminent people agree that corporate law ought to be changed.

The pursuit of truth is very important, just as the pursuit of justice is very important. As Mr Justice Stephen and Mr Justice Aickin of the High Court said in the passage I have quoted, justice is a matter of balance. I have a statement made in 1846 by Vice-Chancellor Sir J. L. Knight Bruce which puts it very well. This case did not involve crime but involved civil proceedings. One of the parties to the case wanted to gain some information. The Vice-Chancellor said that he would not allow it because there really had to be a balance. He made the following statement, which I think is a good one:

SPEECH.PARA: The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise than advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against the solicitor, who, in the case between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton, had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon thought it right to prohibit. Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much. And surely the meanness and the mischief of prying into a man's confidential consultations with his legal adviser, the general evil of infusing reserve and dissimulation, uneasiness, and suspicion and fear, into those communications which must take place, and which, unless in a condition of perfect security, must take place uselessly or worse, are too great a price to pay for truth itself.

I point that out on the basis that simply to say that we want to curb crime, or simply to say that we want to curb truth, does not justify all and every means that might be available to obtain those two great qualities.

PARA.TAB: I am anxious to hear what Senator Lewis has to say about this, but before I sit down I will raise another matter which is incidental to the issue of corporate law. It is very important to ensure the integrity of the corporate sector and to look at the corporate sector closely in circumstances where the move is towards privatisation. The privatisation of industries and services is done through the corporate structure. Indeed, one of the things that worries me about the whole issue of privatisation is that it is to be effected through the corporate structure.

A person who is on the board of a company owes an obligation—and properly so—to the shareholders of that company. That means that the duty is to the shareholders and to the good of the company, which may end up being entirely different from an obligation to act in the public interest.If we go down the path of privatisation, we have to look very carefully at the obligations of directors of companies—indeed, the people who run companies. As I say, their obligation does not lie with the general public, but with the shareholders. It is on that basis that companies go offshore or close down factories that do not seem to be viable or which, when closed down, add to the profit of a company. Those are the sorts of considerations directors take into account according to the Corporations Act. Indeed, if they do not take those proper proceedings, directors can be held civilly or even criminally liable.

One area that has been overlooked in this privatisation debate is how privatisation can be done effectively through the corporate structure. Indeed, that is the only structure through which it can effectively be done. As debate goes on in this chamber, if we are to go down the path of privatisation, we really do have to look at the provisions in the corporations legislation to see whether directors can have a wider regard for the public. It is hard to see how they can, because it is really for the Government to decide what is for the public good and what is in the interests of the electors. Politicians—Ministers, senators and members of Parliament—are elected to do that and it seems a bit hard to impose those obligations on the corporate sector.

However, to take up the point that Senator Spindler was making, it would be proper to ensure that there is integrity in the corporate world when so much more is placed into that area by way of providing services and products for the people of Australia. There is a great argument in favour of not going down the path of privatisation and corporatisation without real consideration of the whole issue. As I am interested in hearing the next speaker, I will resume my seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney does me an honour. I wish to speak to this matter because I am in a somewhat similar difficulty to that of Senator Cooney, in that he should be supporting our amendment and I should be opposing our amendment. However, the way the situation is, I might simply adopt Senator Cooney's remarks in relation to that matter, and no doubt he will stay with his Party and I will stay with my Party.

PARA.TAB: The Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992 appears to arise out of a report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities published in November last year entitled Use Immunity Provisions in the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission Law. I say that it appears to arise out of that report because the Government was about to introduce this legislation in any event. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) had this legislation in mind and the report perhaps just brought it forward. He may have even delayed bringing the legislation forward because he knew that the report was imminent.
I support much of what Senator Cooney said. He summarised it very well in his summary at the end of his dissenting report, on page 35 of the Committee's report. He said:

The law treats the right to silence, as a matter of high principle. The protection it provides against the power of the State should not be diminished in our view, except in accordance with a principle of comparable standing.

SPEECH.PARA: He then went on to say that in his view a principle of that quality has not been advanced in this instance. Although I agree with much of what Senator Cooney had to say, I certainly cannot agree with him dissenting from the views of my very good friend Mr Justice Marks, whom I used to brief in Warrnambool—unfortunately too many years ago.

PARA.TAB: Before I get to the substance of the legislation, as Deputy Chairman of this Committee I would like to mention the people who made submissions to the Committee and, in particular, those people who gave evidence before the Committee. Their names are listed on pages 37 and 38 of the report. I would like to thank those people, because their submissions were certainly worth while and their evidence was most interesting.

The first thing to note about this Bill is that it uses strange words, which even I have difficulty with. It talks about `use immunity' and `derivative use immunity'. That is jargon of the first order. It is all about the common law right to remain silent being overcome by legislation, and then, the immunity arising from that right having been overcome, a qualification in the legislation in some way or other was thought to, and perhaps did, protect witnesses.

The Government's amendments will remove from the Act all reference to the production of a book. As a result, no privilege against self-incrimination shall apply to the production of a book by a witness. The amendments also exempt a body corporate from the effects of the section. In subsection 68(3) reference to the production of a book is removed. The derivative use immunity is removed—that is, immunity arising down the line. Reference to any information, document or other thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person making the statement or signing the record is deleted. Thus, the immunity under subsection 68(3) as amended applies only to the making of a statement or the signing of a record. The amendment being moved by the coalition would restore the original wording, leaving out only the reference to a book—that is, the full immunity and derivative immunity would apply to statements and the signing of the record. In subsection 597(12) the Government's amendments restrict immunity to the answers to questions. No derivative immunity is provided, and the Opposition's amendments would retain the existing wording of subsection 597(12).

This Bill and this report raised a very fine line for the Committee and for this Parliament. That is made clear by the fact that we have people on both sides of the chamber dissenting from the report and people from both sides of the chamber supporting the report. In effect, at hearings conducted by the Australian Securities Commission the right to silence has been removed. The Australian Securities Commission was saying that the fact that the sections provided an indemnity to the persons against the use of the evidence gained indirectly from `leads' provided by the answers to questions or documents produced to the investigators, went so far that the Australian Securities Commission was hamstrung in its prosecutions.

All members of the Committee were very unhappy that no prosecution had been brought forward for the High Court to make a ruling on that matter. In effect, until such time as the High Court gets around to making a ruling on the matter, there is, was and continues to be some doubt as to what the effect of this immunity really is. The Securities Commission and the DPP both argued that should any prosecution of a person so compelled arise, the prosecutor must prove that the evidence being advanced was not gained directly or indirectly from the answers or documents obtained where the privilege against self-incrimination was claimed by the person being examined.

That was very strongly denied by a witness who impressed me enormously: Mr Ehrlich. I refer to paragraph 3.5.3. of the report, in which his argument is set out. He argues that the derivative evidence is only inadmissible if it was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person [witness] making the statement. Thus, all the ASC would need to show, if objection were made . . . was that its normal procedure was to issue notices to produce books in respect of all relevant documentation and that the documentation would . . . have been obtained by the ASC even if it had not been referred to by the witness during examination.

On the other hand, Mr Santow, another witness who impressed me very much, argued that the whole of the corporation law was based on a fiction in that the law enabled a corporation to be established, and, having enabled such a body to be created, obviously by way of rules and regulations, the rules and regulations should not enable it have, in effect, the personal privilege which one grants to a human being. In referring to the Guinness case in the United Kingdom, he said:

. . . what it brought home to people—and it is affecting corporate behaviour—is that it is not just a matter of putting the money back; people actually went to gaol. People like you and me in blue suits and nice shirts went to gaol.

His view was that the penalties ought to apply to corporations because they are established under a fiction and that they should not be able to escape because of the right to silence which we have granted people for centuries under our system of law.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, there is considerable doubt about all of this. I argued very strongly in the Committee along the same lines as Senator Cooney, but in the end I supported the Committee majority for a number of reasons. The first is that the Committee agreed to monitor the use by the ASC of its investigatory powers. I draw the Senate's attention to the powers of the parliamentary Committee under the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 because this Committee has the power to inquire into and report on the activities of the Commission, or the panel, or matters connected with such activities to which, in the parliamentary Committee's opinion, the Parliament's attention should be directed.

In other words, the first and, I think, one of the most significant things that weighed heavily with me was that the Committee itself can inquire into anything connected with these matters. It is not dependent upon a resolution of either House—although that is required if either House resolves to conduct such an investigation. It is not dependent upon the recommendation of the Minister, the Executive Government, the Attorney-General or anyone else. If the Committee wants to inquire into a matter, it can do so. That means that, if a witness is unhappy about the treatment which he or she or his or her company has received at the hands of the ASC, that person can make a complaint to the Committee and the Committee could investigate it, if it wished, regardless of the attitude of the Executive Government and the ASC.

Furthermore, as set out in the report, the Committee has agreed to monitor these investigatory processes. I think there is much merit in the fact that the parliamentary Committee is, in effect, a minder of the minder—the minder of the ASC. It should be a fundamental activity of this Committee, with routine investigations being done regularly—something to which the Committee has, in effect, agreed—and if any member of the public wished to complain, the Committee could receive the complaint and, if it wished to, investigate the matter.

Secondly, I was heavily persuaded by the concern that this matter must be dealt with quickly. There is no appeal to the High Court in the pipeline and we really cannot wait for years and years. The problem is so acute that it must be dealt with straight away.

The final paragraph—which, I think, was put in the Committee's report at my request—is of great importance. It recommends an inquiry into whether the activities of the ASC should be limited to the civil jurisdiction. I have little doubt that the solution to this problem lies in taking that course—that is, that the ASC should be able to act with all of these wide-ranging powers in the civil jurisdiction. It should be able to step in straight away, as soon as there is some fear that a company has acted improperly, appoint a receiver or whatever it has to do, seize the assets, and make sure that creditors and shareholders are protected against the criminal machinations of corporate officers.

The present problem is that the ASC, because it has been continually concerned with the criminal prosecution of such people, is unable to act quickly in the civil jurisdiction. Parliament must look at this matter. The Executive Government and shadow Ministry ought to be looking at the possibility of providing the ASC with access to the civil jurisdiction and allowing the public prosecutor to pursue criminal matters through the normal Commonwealth and State police forces, or through whatever system is deemed appropriate.

I return to my earlier point that there is a very fine line. I found great difficulty at the time of preparing the report in deciding whether I should support the majority view or the dissenting report. Ultimately—and one of the things that weighed with me was that I was the Deputy Chairman of the Committee at the time of the report—I came down in favour of the majority.

Like Senator Cooney, I have put these arguments to my Party and my Party has decided to put forward the amendment that Senator Campbell will be moving in due course. All I can say is: who am I to judge whether I am right or my Party is right? I accept the judgment of my peers in that regard.

In relation to the debate today, and with all due respect to Senator Spindler, he put his case in support of this legislation as though the amendment that we are moving today would protect future investors. I have my doubts about that. How one protects future investors from crooks, I do not know. What one does is prosecute the crooks. As Mr Santow said in his evidence, if one or two of them can be sent to gaol, that may make the others sit up and take notice. However, the truth of the matter is that there will always be crooks trying to find some way around or through the law—committing offences that rob investors and their own shareholders; defrauding people. This legislation will not protect the victims. It may assist with the conviction of some people in the future but, unfortunately, the protection of investors is difficult to ensure. In the last 20 years decency seems to have fallen by the wayside. While there have always been crooks, in the last decade it seems as though the financial crooks of this country have become uncontrollable.

Senator Cooney made reference to the problems involved in corporatisation. While I heard his remarks and I accept and agree with much of what he was saying, I draw his attention to what his Government has done in relation to corporatisation. The Government has taken a large number of Government instrumentalities out of the control of the Parliament and given them a degree of independence. Yet who are the shareholders who might control those corporate bodies?

It is one of my great concerns with our large public companies that the shareholders really should be represented by the directors. In many cases they are represented by the directors and many of those directors do a good job. But, from time to time, one wonders when companies make bad decisions. Let me give an example. Look at what the banks did during the 1980s. They were in such enormous competition with each other and they were so determined to ensure that the new banks which had come in from overseas would not get a foothold in Australia that they were frequently lending enormous sums of money to companies on the basis of some sort of an undertaking. They were not even examining the companies' full statements of assets, liabilities and other commitments. On the basis of some sort of undertaking by a director of a company, or a resolution of a company, a bank would lend it enormous sums of money. One is aware of a situation where an enormous sum of money was lent on a Sunday morning as a result of a telephone call.

Who was protecting the rights of the shareholders in those matters? Where were the other public companies, in particular the life assurance companies which have enormous investments in these public companies? What were they saying to the directors of those public companies? Very little, unfortunately, it appears.

That is a problem for public companies. I say to Senator Cooney that his Party has, in my view, set up a situation for which some poor Minister will end up carrying the can at some stage down the track. I do not know when it will be: five, 10, 15 years time. But in due course, somewhere down the track, unless my Party manages to totally privatise those corporations that the Government has established, one can bet there will be major problems because the only shareholder in a lot of those organisations is the Commonwealth of Australia, in effect, the Executive Government. So the directors of those corporations and the Minister will be able to do deals. There will be no responsibility to this Parliament. Senators will not hear about it until the whole thing explodes.

Of course, from time to time it may very well appear that the executive officers of that corporate body owned by the Commonwealth may get themselves into some sort of difficulty as a result of which they may not tell the Minister the full truth. They may report to the Minister in a very clever way whereby they will be able to say, `Oh, yes. We told you that, Minister. If you read on page 85, paragraph 7(vi), there is one sentence which in effect implies that we had borrowed more than we should have borrowed' or something along those lines.

I say to the Labor Party—and I say to Senator Cooney in particular—that this Government has established this situation. It has even gone further; some of those bodies, such as the Commonwealth Bank, have a small public interest and an enormous Commonwealth interest. If ever there are possibilities of problems, that must surely be the prime example. I say to the Government that it went half way because of the difficulties of finding finance. But it has taken these bodies out of the control of the Parliament and, in effect, placed them in the hands of corporate officers whose responsibility will be to no more than one Minister. That Minister will have, in effect, a responsibility to the Cabinet, and the Cabinet, ultimately, to the Party. It is too remote in my view and fraught with difficulty.

I raise that with Senator Cooney only because he, in the course of his remarks in relation to this Bill, made reference to the corporation problems and the problems of directors. That, I say again, is another matter which the Senate ought to be considering; that is, directors have enormous responsibilities now. Some of them, as we are seeing for example with Compass Airlines, may be extraordinarily difficult.

There is one group of people associated with companies which may not suffer those difficulties. I am referring to consultants. If it is possible for a person to become a consultant to a company, then it may very well be that that consultant can avoid the responsibilities and obligations that would come from being the directors of the company. For all we know, that person may in fact, as a consultant, be the one who is controlling what that company is doing. One can imagine a situation where, in effect, men of straw are appointed as the directors of the company and the real controller is appointed simply as a consultant to the company and he uses the men of straw to achieve a particular end.
The law on this matter is getting fatter and fatter yet there will always be opportunities for fraud and, unfortunately, there will always be people who will take advantage of those opportunities.
