TALK.START.PARA: —There is one amendment relating to clause 43 which was put to the Committee, which was not accepted by the Committee and which the Democrats would like to put to this Committee of the Whole. Clause 43 deals with the rehabilitation of mine sites. It seeks to insert after section 124BB of the principal Act the following subsection:

SPEECH.PARA: (1A) A reference in this section to the restoration of a site includes a reference to the partial restoration of the site (even if the taxpayer had no intention of completing the restoration).

The effect of this amendment is to allow tax deductibility for partial restoration of a mine site. The Oxford English Dictionary defines `restore' as `bring back or attempt to bring back to the original state'. The use of the term `restoration' in clause 43 is a misuse of the English language. The taxation process should be used as an instrument of social policy. That is a point we have made very often in the past. The Government has claimed on a number of occasions that it is committed to ecologically sustainable development. The taxation system is, as I have said on many occasions, a way in which the externalities in much of our economic process can be written into the costs.

PARA.TAB: There are many costs in the processes of using resources—costs in relation to environmental damage and the pollution which results both from the mining and from the use of those resources further down the track. Every single economist says that we need to internalise those externalities if, indeed, we are going to get to what the Opposition fondly calls a level playing field. Only in that way will we have costs properly represented in the economic system with people making judgments founded on the proper costs. This Government amendment to clause 31 seeks to allow 100 per cent tax deductibility for partial restoration, whatever that means.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you read the Tax Office's explanation? Didn't you read the Hansard of the Committee?

—Yes, as a matter of fact I did read it and I am not convinced by it. I am well aware that the Tax Office has this peculiar view of taxation—that taxation is simply a way of raising revenue and has little relationship with the way in which we deliberately want to move society. We want to influence the decisions that people make in relation to the way in which they spend money.
—But opposing the clause won't achieve your aim.

—To some extent I would have to agree with Senator Coates. It would be better if one could come up with a sliding scale of claims—that would be our preferred position—in that if there were some partial restoration, there might be some partial claim. Under the circumstances, we believe that it is better to draw attention to this matter by opposing it and then, hopefully, the Government will come forward with a plan of graded tax concessions.

PARA.TAB: Mining is a major industry in Australia. That has long been the case and will continue to be the case into the foreseeable future. The Australian mining industry is a world leader in a number of areas and is very competitive internationally. Mining—and here I include quarrying—is a special industry. It involves a unique right. It involves the right to extract natural minerals from the earth, minerals which are owned in common by all citizens of Australia. The right to mine is the granting of an exclusive right to a particular person to the use for the time being of those resources.

The Australian Democrats argue that the granting of these rights must be balanced by an obligation on the part of the extractor to rehabilitate the mine site. Given our historical constitutional arrangements, most onshore mining is conducted under the administration of State governments. Thus, it is those State governments which impose the conditions on the exploitation of our minerals and also prescribe the rehabilitation which must be undertaken in exchange for the right to undertake the mining operation.

As is usual under our archaic system, there are myriad differing rules and regulations which obtain in the various States. Some States require full rehabilitation as a matter of law. Some simply rely on ad hoc licence conditions. When I was in Western Australia recently looking at sandmining operations, I was rather shocked to find that the requirement under the State law there was merely the restoration of at least 10 per cent of the species and areas that have undergone sandmining. The area might look rehabilitated, but to any trained botanist it is grossly deficient in species that were there before.

The Australian Democrats support the concept of compulsory mine site rehabilitation. This does not mean that there may not be some circumstances when it is appropriate to rehabilitate the site into a public recreation area, as has already occurred in some areas such as Penrith Lakes in Sydney, instead of back to its original state. To help to ensure that the mine site is fully rehabilitated, we must have a system of taxation incentives which maximise the benefits to those who maximise the rehabilitation. Clause 43 proposes that all rehabilitation expenditure be fully deductible, even where there is no intention to fully restore the mine site. This is a deliberate move by the Government to undermine—and no pun is intended here—sustainable development. As such, the Democrats oppose the clause.

In the Committee hearing last Friday, which Senator Kernot could not attend because of her duties on the Aboriginal Reconciliation Council, the Tax Office put the view that this amendment is not necessary; it changes nothing. If that is the case, why are we wasting taxpayers' money in bringing the amendment before the Parliament? Certainly the industry, at whose behest this amendment was drafted, was concerned enough to convince the Government to proceed with the amendment. The actual wording of the original provisions of section 124BA(1) of the Assessment Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: A deduction is allowable in respect of rehabilitation-related activities as defined.
Section 124BB(1) states:

A reference in this Division to a rehabilitation-related activity in relation to a taxpayer is a reference to the restoration of a site on which the taxpayer conducted extractive activities to, or to a reasonable approximation of, the pre-mining condition of the site.

There is absolutely no doubt that the current law only applies to restoration; there is no specific reference to partial restoration. In addition, the reference to `a reasonable approximation of the pre-mining condition' is clearly an indication of the fact that a deduction is not allowed for a partial restoration as the law now stands.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats acknowledge the comments of Senator Watson at page 46 of the transcript of the Committee hearing who said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be supporting that Democrat amendment because at all times the Opposition has pushed for the recognition of a partial restoration. We acknowledge that in the original amendments which provided for rehabilitation provisions, there was some doubt about the deductibility in circumstances of a partial restoration.
At least the Opposition is being honest in its position here. It is not acting like the Government and claiming that the amendment does not do anything.

PARA.TAB: Under common usage, we do not restore—and I am coming back to the Oxford definition here—a piece of furniture if we partially fix it; it is only restored if it is completely restored. Similarly, if a mine has a 200-foot tailings dump, it is not restored if only half the tailings are removed. What we need is a system of taxation incentives which tend to maximise the amount of environmental restoration our industries undertake, and minimise the amount of environmental damage that they cause. That is a sine qua non of ecologically sustainable development. This proposal means that full deductibility is granted whether a superb rehabilitation is undertaken or whether an inadequate procedure is settled for. This Government amendment can do nothing other than deter full mine site rehabilitation and, therefore, the Democrats will insist on our amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal-National Party coalition again will not support the Australian Democrats' amendment. We stand by our original position which is stated in the Hansard of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration of Friday, 1 May. I would like to point out to the honourable senator from the Democrats, Senator Coulter, that this amendment could result in situations which are quite unjust. It could work unfairly in respect of a partial restoration regime in situations where a company spent, say, $100,000 but, according to the Democrats' amendment, I understand could only be entitled to $50,000 where that partial restoration represented only 50 per cent of the potential 100 per cent restoration.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that the Australian Democrats do not provide us with any help on a definition. I believe that the Australian Democrats' case could have been supported had they provided a comprehensive definition of what they refer to as `restoration'. Senator Coulter gave an example of where only 50 per cent of the tailings were removed. How would the Democrats cover a situation where 50 per cent of the tailings had been left and they were covered by special grasses, trees, et cetera? I feel that that would cause a whole host of subjective problems.

I believe that the Senate should be very careful about using the Income Tax Assessment Act as an instrument of social policy. As an instrument of social policy in terms of ensuring that people who have a higher income pay a higher rate of tax, yes, I think that is reasonable. Once we start going out into other areas of social justice, human resource management or environmental matters and using the Act to enforce them, the Act would become even more incomprehensible than it now is. I submit to the Senate that perhaps the practice of previous governments in trying to do too much with the Income Tax Assessment Act in this area has caused problems in the past.

I take this opportunity to congratulate the Australian mining industry on responding magnificently with respect to rehabilitation. The great majority of rehabilitation programs around the country are a credit to those companies involved. There will always be isolated examples. I think it is appropriate that the income tax legislation acknowledge fully the money that has been spent and the work that has been done in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow on from what I said during the second reading debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 and also to take up the remarks of Senator Coulter. Senator Coulter's main argument, if I understand it correctly, is not to allow depreciation for partial restoration. I do not think there are too many in this chamber who have practical mining experience, and I happen to have some of that experience. I know that it is the Australian Democrats' ongoing agenda to close all mining, but I will ignore that for now.

—Senator Bell should know that rehabilitation starts even before mining does. I refer to gold mining, the area in which I have experience. There is a corporate tax on gold, so one has to allow for depreciation. If one expends so much on rehabilitation in one year, surely one should be able to claim 100 per cent. As I said, rehabilitation starts even before mining begins. If one is doing an open cut pit and wants to rehabilitate slime dumps or mullock dumps, one clears the site, removes the trees and puts them aside, and also one removes the topsoil and puts it aside.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter argues that there should only be 100 per cent rehabilitation when the job has been done. In that case there cannot be ongoing rehabilitation, and it must be ongoing. When one starts building mullock dumps one has to start putting the topsoil on when the first bench is completed. It is no good doing six, seven or eight benches which reach 100 or 150 metres into the sky. How would one put topsoil on that? One starts when one finishes the first bench; one starts to pour it over the sides. When one does the next bench, one pours over some more, and so on. Because topsoil has been put on the mullock dumps, the last bench is virtually the finished job. How can Senator Coulter tell me that we cannot have ongoing depreciation for ongoing work? If that is the case, it is patently unfair with respect to the taxation regime and as a practical consideration.

Senator Coulter said that we should remove mullock dumps and also get the area back to the pre-mining condition. Senator Coulter was referring to sand mining, which might be different from gold mining. What would we do with the mullock dumps from gold mining? We can put the material back in the pit, but by the time that is done no open gold mine in Australia would be profitable. What is more, the mining laws in Western Australia say that we cannot refill pits or shafts. If we drop the lease, we have to give someone the chance to access the work that we have done. I am sure that those laws are still contained in the mining legislation of Western Australia. We have to leave access for someone else if we decide to give the lease away. If Senator Coulter meant that those dumps were to go back into the pit, his suggestion contravenes the mining laws of Western Australia. If he wants the mullock dumps to go back into the pit, it will put any gold mine, unless it is a fantastically rich one, out of the running altogether.

As a matter of commonsense, if we want to ensure that rehabilitation is ongoing and that a company does not finish a mine off by leaving a big hole or a big dump and then walking away from it, there are provisions in the mining Act of Western Australia for a percentage of the amount represented by the gold we extract to be spent on rehabilitation. If that process is left right to the end, it cannot be done properly. If there is not 100 per cent tax deductibility, there is no encouragement to undertake that work. I would like Senator Coulter and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to take note of what I have said on this topic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Watson and Senator Panizza seem to have failed, at two levels, to understand the argument that is being put. They have failed to read the words which appear in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 and which are, `. . . even if the taxpayer had no intention of completing the restoration. . . '. It seems to me that that is a very important qualifier which demolishes everything that Senator Panizza has just said. Both Senator Watson and Senator Panizza seem to be unaware that the requirements in relation to restoration and what that means is usually determined, as Senator Watson identified, under State law. The 100 per cent restoration would be in conformity with the requirements under State law. We are saying that where people fail to fulfil those requirements under the State law to 100 per cent, they should not be eligible for tax deductibility.
—State law does not require 100 per cent.
—If State law in Tasmania does not require restoration, perhaps people down there need to give some attention to that. But that is outside this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Usually, as we certainly find in South Australia, the law sets certain requirements in relation to restoration. Clearly, restoration in the terms of this clause would mean 100 per cent restoration with respect to those requirements; yet this Bill seeks to give tax deductibility when only partial restoration of the site has been carried out, even if the taxpayer has no intention of completing the restoration. It seems to the Australian Democrats that, on the one hand, that is encouraging people not to complete the task that they are or should be charged with and, on the other hand, providing them with encouragement to not proceed with the work to full restoration according to the requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —If State law said that it is only 70 per cent and they went to 100 per cent, could they get a reduction?
—No. We are foreshadowing a more ideal situation if a formula could be worked out in which there would be some partial tax deductibility for partial restoration.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—Senator Coulter, I believe in those remarks that you are responding to something that Senator Watson said. I suspect that the rest of the chamber is not au fait with it. I only hope that Hansard is. If you would speak through the Chair, it would help.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will elaborate. To use Senator Watson's example, if full restoration costs $100,000 and $100,000 is spent, $100,000 can be claimed as a tax deduction. On the other hand, if only $50,000 is spent and the site is half restored, again that full $50,000 can be claimed as a tax deduction. We are arguing that a much lesser incentive should be put in here for that expenditure as an encouragement to fully restore the site to back up the requirements which are often in place, and evidently are not in place in Tasmania, under State law.

PARA.TAB: To encourage the Government to go down that road, we are saying that clause 43 should be opposed and deleted. We hope that the Government would then come forward with a more appropriately graded set of tax deductions which would put that sort of encouragement into place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond very briefly. That 100 per cent restoration may not be practical or even aesthetically desirable or environmentally sound. It would be putting an unnecessary further imposition on the mining industry that is not necessarily in either its interests or, in some circumstances, the interests of sound environmental restoration.

—Senator Coulter is trying to convince us to support him in what he is attempting to do. I wonder how he proposes to fully restore an open pit gold mine. I can see the way that he is going. He knows as well as I do that it is impossible. All he wants to do is remove the tax deductibility for what one does by a certain percentage.

—The Government does not support this amendment. To some extent, the reasons were outlined in the Committee. I was not able to attend the Committee on this occasion. However, I thank Senator Button and the Committee for its deliberations.

PARA.TAB: I want to make three points. I do not want to take much of the Committee's time. The reason we have legislation committees is so these issues can be argued elsewhere. Firstly, we are dealing with not a mining Bill but a tax Bill. If people want to require compulsory rehabilitation, the place to do that is in the mining Acts in the various States, not in the tax Bill. In fact, the tax Bill cannot do it. Even if we wished to do it, the tax Bill cannot do it; it is not possible. That is the first point. Whichever version of the clause—that is, the existing clause or the amended clause—were to be the law of the land, neither would require compulsory 100 per cent rehabilitation.

We are talking here about the circumstances in which deductibility should be available for mine site rehabilitation. It has been said, and it remains the Government's view, that the existing clause allows claims on partial rehabilitation. But there was doubt and some uncertainty about that. It remains our view that that was the better interpretation of the Act as it stands, but to make it clear, we have proposed this amendment which, it is now agreed, does make that situation unequivocal.

It is a public good that work should be expended to rehabilitate mine sites. We want companies to do that. To the extent that they spend money so rehabilitating, it should be tax deductible. It is very unusual for expenditure conducted in the normal course of running a business not to be deductible. It would be an extraordinary situation if, amongst all the expenditures that companies might have, we were to isolate partial rehabilitation as something which is not deductible. Companies can do all sorts of other things of which people may or may not approve, but those expenses are incurred in the normal course of running their businesses, so they are tax deductible.

It is proposed that one expenditure which is socially desirable, but perhaps not as socially desirable as some other expenditure—that is, 100 per cent rehabilitation—be plucked out of the normal course of business expenditure and made an exception. It is true that, in the distant past, rehabilitation was not deemed to be deductible for reasons about which we do not now need to worry. We are saying that this is expenditure which businesses are, and should be, now required to conduct and that therefore it should be deductible.

The second points relates a little to what Senator Panizza was saying. I thought there was a lot of validity in some of his points. I will express it differently, but it is consistent with the point he was making. It is quite likely that there will be circumstances at the end of a financial year when it is not possible objectively to establish whether the expenditure on rehabilitation is part of a 100 per cent rehabilitation because the process is only half finished. There has been expenditure in the financial year on mine site rehabilitation, but the process is unfinished.

Is that total or partial rehabilitation? Does the claim have to be put off until the work is finished to prove retrospectively that the expenditure was justifiable? Can the expense be claimed this year on the basis of the assertion that it is a complying expenditure with the money then having to be paid back in subsequent years because it is not deemed to be a full restoration? It will not work. I have to say that at the moment the proposed clause is better this way.

The other point I reiterate is that the amendment does not achieve its objective anyway because it is the prevailing view that, even if the existing clause were to remain, partial restoration would still be deductible. The essential point is that we do not want to have this as a proxy for the mining Act. I do not take quite as purist a view as Senator Watson, who says that we should not be using this for social policy purposes. I understand his argument; it is an orthodox argument of many people. People who are used to hearing me debate tax Bills will know that I do not take such a purist view. In some instances, I am prepared to support the use of not just the income tax laws but also the sales tax laws to achieve social and environmental objectives. So it is not that, as a matter of fundamental principle, that is a hurdle over which I am not prepared to jump sometimes. But it certainly is not and cannot be a proxy for proper State legislation with regard to mine site rehabilitation.

I do not want to take any more of the Committee's time. The argument has been pretty well rehearsed. I note that it was essentially conducted in the Committee in preparatory mode. It has been done here again today. I do not have anything to add. We will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to Government amendments and new clauses to be moved to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I received and looked at the amendments that the Government was proposing to move to its own legislation in what can only be described as sheer amazement. The supplementary explanatory memorandum says:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments proposed to this Bill are primarily technical drafting changes and clarifications of several sections of the Customs Act 1901 arising from the electronic lodgement proposals in Clauses 13 and 16 of the Bill.

Quite frankly, the explanatory memorandum is longer than the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. It is certainly longer than the second reading speech. Even the several pages of amendments themselves simply make plain the lack of consultation that the industry has complained of and which we dealt with in speeches during the second reading debate. I understand that this Bill was in a draft form at the end of last year. Here we are dealing with it in May. It was not made available to the industry to discuss or to comment upon. There was great consternation about the way in which the agreement was entered into to allow the—(Quorum formed)

PARA.TAB: I was saying that these amendments, which purport to be technical in nature, underscore the fact that the legislation was badly drafted. Like so much of the legislation that this Government brings in, we have to amend it subsequently to fix up the errors that were left in it.

If we read the language of the outline and look at the nature of the amendments, we see that they are far from being technical. They are substantial and very important amendments. As I said, they underline the lack of discussion with the industry which was complained of and the way in which the system was brought into play prior to the legislative framework being in place. The whole thing has been quite slovenly done.

I return to a statement that I made today when I was commenting on the Auditor-General's report. So much of the sloppy work that comes through in terms of what appears to be administration of government policy has to be sheeted home to the Minister. It is the Minister who is paid to be responsible. It is up to him to ensure that things are done properly. I am afraid that the situation is getting worse. Ministers will have to be accountable for poor legislation. In this case we have both the senior Minister in this place, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Button, and the junior Minister, the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs, Mr Beddall, in the other place. All I can say is that if either of them can be proud of the way in which this legislation has been presented and dealt with, they are not up to being called Ministers of the Crown.

When this matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, the Opposition indicated that it would certainly agree to the amendments. TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to move that the Committee report progress. That might sound like a very peremptory move at this stage but, while we are dealing with the substance of this amendment at one level, we are also dealing with a situation in which, as I understand it, there is to be a court hearing on Thursday. While the court hearing does not go to the substance of whether 37 of the detainees who have been held in custody for some considerable time are or are not refugees, nonetheless, the people involved have a case before the courts which goes to the matter of whether they should be held in custody or released.

PARA.TAB: It seems to the Australian Democrats that to proceed at this stage and to cut off that line of appeal, while that matter is before the courts, is far more peremptory than the action I am taking here in foreshadowing a motion that the Committee report progress. I believe that this matter should be held over and considered after the passage of a bit more time. There are many people out in the community who have not had an opportunity to look at this legislation.

While on balance I would come down in favour of the legislation, I concede that it is a very finely balanced judgment. To pass this legislation at this time, in the very hasty manner in which it has been brought forward, is, I think, unsatisfactory for those very many people in the community who are affected by it; more particularly, in relation to those 37 people, each of whom will have reasons—probably quite separate reasons—to have gone to court to seek their release from custody and their release into the Australian community.

A characteristic of this Parliament should be not to seek to pass laws to cover up for mistakes which the Government has made. As for the actual hearings in relation to the status of these people, whether refugees or not, my understanding is that there was a flaw in the proceedings by which these people were being dealt with. That was corrected in the sense that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) has instructed the appeals committee to go back and review the procedures and to consider the appeals in the correct manner. Perhaps that in itself has led to some delay.

To attempt to correct that situation by passing hasty legislation through this Parliament, and to close off a legitimate source of appeal which exists within the law as it is, seems to us to be quite unconscionable. It is for those reasons that we very strongly suggest to the Committee that it should not proceed with this legislation tonight but should allow a great deal more time to pass—at least until the next sitting period—so that those both within the Parliament and outside have an opportunity to look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have run that argument last night.

—In that particular case, we all knew the outcome of the debate. Really, that was a matter of filibustering. In this case we have 37 people who have an appeal before the court. The matter is to be heard on Thursday and to proceed at this time, to change the law at this time, when those people have already lodged their appeals is without conscience. I believe that, for that reason, we should not proceed at this time. We should hold this matter over and consider it later in the next sitting period to allow a reasonable period of time for those both within and outside the Parliament to have a look to see just exactly what this legislation does and, in the meantime, not cut off that legitimate court action by those 37 people. It is for that reason I urge most strongly that the Senate not proceed at this time. Accordingly, I have foreshadowed a motion to report progress.

PARA.TAB: Anyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings before a court, in order that that court may decide without delay on the lawfulness of his detention and order his release if the detention is not lawful.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that if this Committee tonight proceeds to intervene in the legal process concerning those Cambodian boat people, those 37 individuals, it will be in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which this nation is a signatory. TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. I think that is an eminently desirable procedure and I thank you for putting the Committee right. I would support the foreshadowed motion; that is, that we report progress. I am not debating that necessarily at the moment. What I wish to say to the Committee is, I believe, extremely important. It is this: when the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs gave a briefing to my office about these amendments, it did not mention in any shape or form the fact that there was a case pending before Mr Justice O'Loughlin of the Federal Court in Melbourne at 9.15 a.m. this coming Thursday—that is, the day after tomorrow. The Department did not indicate to me or to my staff that this was a major reason for these amendments.

PARA.TAB: If the Department and the Minister are going to be up-front on these particular matters, they should have told me; they should have told my staff. This particular aspect of this measure is very disconcerting indeed. There is a case pending before Mr Justice O'Loughlin of the Federal Court in Melbourne at 9.15 a.m. this Thursday. This measure says something to Mr Justice O'Loughlin in terms the likes of which I have not seen in any other measure that has come before us.
Clause 54N(2) on page 3 of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that subsection even applies to a designated person who was held in a place described in paragraph 11(a). . .

That is an extraordinary inclusion of the word `even'. It is telling the judge, `Let us make it perfectly clear to you that you cannot hear this case further'. That is extraordinary, because this is a question of the right of a person or a group of persons to liberty under the rule of law. Litigation is pending, and the Minister is a party to that case. Parliament is being used in this circumstance to bolster the Minister's case. I do not think that is fair or reasonable.

PARA.TAB: The cases that I referred to are in the names of refugees. The cases are the Lyieng and Others case, the Chueng Lim case and the 22 Cambodians. Some of these people have been in isolated detention since November 1989. The action is being taken to seek to have the applicants cared for or looked after by certain groups, including the Catholic church, the Anglican church, the Uniting church and the St Vincent de Paul Society, on whose recognisance these persons would be released.

It is not a question of whether they are refugees; their status will be determined in another way. These people have been in isolation and have an application before the Federal Court. They deserve to have their application considered. It will not cost the Government. In fact, it will save the Government. It costs over $200 a day for each of these persons to be kept in detention. As I understand it, these charity groups would be picking up a substantial part of that tab.

The implications of these amendments are quite startling. There is a denial of due process and the rule of law. The question has been raised of the arbitrary nature of the proposed further detentions. There is a question as to whether it is contrary to the Constitution, and indeed there is a real question as to whether this measure is being undertaken in unconscionable haste. In addition, there is the one I mentioned before, the suppression of the real intent, which is to interfere in the case which is pending before the Federal Court.

Let us remember the Torres Strait Islander case in 1982 which dealt with property rights. That case involved Torres Strait Islanders, and a Minister of the Queensland Government was also a party to that case. In 1985 the Minister put through the Queensland Cabinet a proposal to introduce a Bill into the Queensland Parliament called the Queensland Coastal Islands Declaratory Act. The purpose of that Act was the same as is intended by Mr Hand under this legislation. It was to defeat the litigation that was pending in the High Court.

A number of the judges described that measure, which is identical to this measure, as draconian. We are talking about draconian measures here. We are talking about measures that are a denial of due process and the rule of law. We are also talking about measures which, I believe, would not be countenanced by the international legal community.

I have a report in my hand which was prepared by the Acting Secretary of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission as a result of the Acting Secretary's visit to the refugee camps at Darwin and Port Hedland. If the Minister has not as yet tabled that report, I am prepared to table it in the Parliament tonight because I think it is relevant to this matter. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission raises several issues in its report. I will deal with just a couple of them. Paragraph 5 of the report talks about broader issues arising from conditions observed at Port Hedland. Bear in mind that 23 of the applicants, I think, have been held for some considerable time. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Remoteness, isolation and long term detention. As has been noted, many aspects of the conditions and facilities at Port Hedland were particularly good. The detainees generally spoke favourably of the staff. The basic standard of accommodation is good and there are encouraging plans providing more vocational classes and cultural activities.
It goes on:

Most of the problems that have been identified have their basis in the very fact of detention—its long term nature and the lack of provisions for any alternative. This exacerbates the problems that have given rise to human rights concerns throughout this report and leads me to question the need for extended detention in any such centre, in particular, in an isolated location. Moreover, such detention itself raises human rights issues directly.

The report talks about the Convention on the Status of Refugees. It also talks about the question of religion. It raises the issue of whether the activities that are being oversighted by the Department are in accord with article 9 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and article 31 (1) of the Convention on the Status of Refugees and, so far as religion is concerned, article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Committee is faced with a most onerous task tonight. The only other comparable situation for the Government's current action relating to detainees is that which was taken during World War II. That was under emergency and wartime powers when the foreign nationals were thought to threaten the security of the nation. Nobody would suggest that the security of the nation is threatened, least of all until Thursday morning when the matter comes before the courts. I would have thought that it is reasonable for the Committee to consider that question and to support the proposal that the Committee report progress.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Aulich)—Senator Harradine, do you wish to table those documents now? If you do wish to, you will need to seek leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to show them to us.

—I would rather they not be tabled at this stage. Maybe Senator Harradine can listen to what I might say at this stage and consider whether he wants to proceed with trying to table them.
—Senator Harradine, you can seek leave at any time to have them tabled so we will come back to that later.

—The Government strenuously opposes the manoeuvre that the Australian Democrats are attempting this evening with the assistance of Senator Harradine. I do not know what has driven this. I must admit that when I was listening to PM tonight, I thought to myself that a proposal which was destined for plain sailing through the Senate tonight probably would be more anxiously debated than we had anticipated. I felt that Senator Coulter, driven by concern about his Party's performance in the polls, might want to create a new persona, a new image, for himself—and what better issue, especially when the ABC and PM have had something to say about it?

PARA.TAB: What we have before us tonight is not a new issue. At any time over the last two years anyone could have argued what Senator Coulter, Senator Spindler and Senator Harradine have argued tonight. At any time into the future, anyone could argue the same point. At any time during those last two years, one could have found a person claiming refugee status in custody in Australia. Senator Coulter could come in here and argue that that person's rights would be affected by any attempt by government to legislate to cover this area. So I do not accept that it is a new issue, and I do not accept that the timing is inappropriate. As I say, no time is a good time. No time for the last two years has been a good time. No time into the foreseeable future will be a good time in terms of the criteria set by Senator Coulter and Senator Spindler.

What we are talking about and trying to embody in legislation here is the old, long held principle—one that governments of both persuasions have pursued and one that governments of both persuasions have held as a pivotal part of immigration policy—that anyone who enters Australia in an unauthorised way is held in custody until their case is determined. It is not a new principle; it is an old one. We are attempting here tonight to have Parliament assert that principle in legislation. That is what we are on about. That was made very clear by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) today in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have done it months or years ago. You didn't have to do it while the court case was actually in progress.

—As I said, Senator Coulter could have come in at any time. If we had moved this two years and one day ago, he could have come in and said, `No, it's the wrong time; a person's rights are being affected'. The way the system is going at the moment, Senator Coulter could come into the chamber in five years time and make the same assertion. The Government is determined, as has been spelt out very clearly by the Minister, to ensure that there is an orderly assessment of claims, an orderly process, which does not prejudice or gazump those with legitimate claims.

PARA.TAB: What does this legislation affect? It needs to be made clear that the legislation and the points that honourable senators have raised do not affect the definition of one's status—whether one is a refugee or not. That is the most basic question when one is trying to determine whether a person can or cannot stay in Australia. It is the definition of `refugee' and the processing of claims for refugee status which are vitally important. This legislation affects whether those persons who are making those claims stay in custody or are allowed to roam free through the Australian community. It has been a long-held principle that they stay in custody.

The legislation also does not affect the application of the international covenant as it may be interpreted by Australian courts. The international covenant defines `refugee' and `refugee status' and the legislation does not affect the application of the international covenant in Australian law. It would be interpreted in the way that it would otherwise be interpreted by the Australian court process.

We are trying to put the issue of whether a person does or does not stay in custody beyond doubt. This has been a problem and it has been acknowledged broadly in the community as being a problem. I feel sorry for anyone in the position of having to make decisions here. On the one hand, we get the sorts of interventions that we have had tonight and, on the other hand, we get claims that the Government is being too soft. The Government needs to put in place a process which is fair, which recognises legitimate refugee status and which recognises legitimate processes.

We need to put in place a process which has claims considered expeditiously. We need to put into that process some incentive for those claims to be raised, to be progressed, to be heard and to be determined. That is why the Government will not support this deferral motion tonight. The reasons for this deferral motion, had they been raised at any time in recent years and were they to be raised in the future, would be as relevant as they are tonight. No time is a good time to raise this.

In closing, I refer to the draft report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. That draft report is one to which the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has responded. There are some major disagreements in terms of the underlying principles which have driven the Human Rights Commissioner. I am informed that there are some major disagreements in terms of facts that the Commission asserts and the Department disputes.

It would be premature to make that report public when there are such matters in dispute. Not only would it be premature, but it would also pre-empt the process totally. It would put the Human Rights Commission in an extremely difficult position because it would be politicised. A draft report is not a final report; there is a process that has to be gone through. That process is there to ensure that any mistakes in facts—any problems that can be ironed out—are ironed out and that, at the end of the day, a sustainable report comes out of the process.

If that draft report is tabled tonight, it will be very difficult for the Human Rights Commission to come down later in the process with a re-assessed report, given the degree of public debate and the degree of dissension which would immediately and directly emanate from a premature releasing of a draft report. I would not be keen to see that report tabled tonight. However, I am keen to ensure that that process, as has been provided by law, continues down the course that this Parliament has determined and that, at the end of the day, we can get a final report that is sustainable.

I do not think I need to speak much longer. We need to get through this legislation as expeditiously as possible. I reiterate that there is no good reason for deferring the legislation tonight. In fact, there are many good reasons why we should embody in legislation what governments in this country have believed for a long time and what is imperative in order to have a process which can work, and that is the principle that if persons enter Australia in an unauthorised way, then they stay in custody until their status is determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to the case for delaying the matter basically until after Thursday's court case, which is really what this discussion is all about at the moment. Let us not get involved in any deeper issues; this is simply what this motion is about.

PARA.TAB: We have to ask ourselves to what extent delaying the debate will alter the merits of the legislation. On the admission of Senator Harradine, delaying the debate will not alter the merits of the discussion whatsoever. Senator Harradine is now very well informed. There is no doubt that initially he was not. It is a matter of some concern that, as it appears on the face of it, there was clearly an attempt to divert him from some matters of fact which happen to be very germane to the issue.

But that does not alter the basic point that debating the matter now will not in any way alter the merits of the legislation. However, it will alter its impact, because it will impact before Thursday's court case. All this rests on whether it will impact before Thursday's court case.

Quite frankly, the point made by Senator Bolkus, the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, that any time any such action was taken would impact on something relating to illegal immigrants is absolutely correct. We have to look here at a concept that does not come up enough in our discussions about immigration: what is in Australia's best interests? We have here a clash of some very deeply held principles. I understand Senator Harradine's principles. They are principles that have prompted the Catholic church in particular to take a very strong view on this matter.
But it is not a black and white issue simply of one side of this debate being principled and the other side being unprincipled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was trying to deal only with the legal situation.

—I understand that. That is why it would be very useful to have a debate now—because, as I said, there is no merit in delaying that debate in terms of the legislation itself—to see what the merits of the legislation are. Is it in Australia's best interests or not? We have not heard one comment from those who seek to defer it about whether the legislation is in Australia's best interests and whether it is in Australia's best interests to defer it.

PARA.TAB: We have heard that the legislation conflicts with some particular principles. When there is a clash of principles, one has to establish how that conflict will be resolved. We have a basic right to our own integrity as a nation. We have a right to our, if you like, self-determination. Let us recognise that one of the problems in this matter arises out of a very simple issue—that is, the totally spurious distinction between persons who are arrested before disembarking from a boat and persons who arrive by boat, enter undetected and are then arrested. That really goes to the heart of the sorts of problems we face.

It appears to me that the Government is totally right in adopting the sort of procedure it adopts in tax cases. If it sees a similar situation, it says, `Righto, we will chop that off as of now'. In many instances, it takes far too long to get the legislation right. This legislation certainly was not right originally. I can see no problems, neither in principle nor in terms of Australia's best interests, with proceeding to resolve this matter with the sort of informed debate that clearly can take place now. As I understand it, no-one is suggesting that a debate dealing with the merits of the legislation now would not be informed or effective.

The complaint is that the result of having a debate now would impinge on the human rights of a particular group of people who somehow are more significant than other groups of people who, no matter what time it was done, would have their rights `impinged on'. If the Democrats and Senator Harradine say, `But the difference of degree is so enormous in this case that it becomes a difference of kind', I would like them to demonstrate that to me.

Let this chamber and this Parliament concentrate on what is in Australia's best interests. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not agree more with Senator Baume that the legislation should be passed in Australia's best interests. The AAP report tonight states that Minister Hand told the House of Representatives that it is crucial that people who come to Australia without prior approval not be released into the community. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is determined that a clear signal be sent that migration to Australia may not be achieved by simply arriving in this country and expecting to be allowed into the community.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler quoted the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which I repeat:
Anyone who is deprived of his liberty by arrest or detention shall be entitled to take proceedings before a court—

SPEECH.PARA: which has been done—
in order that that court may decide without delay on the lawfulness of his detention and order his release if that detention is not lawful.

What is happening here is that midstream the question of whether it is lawful is being changed. What may be unlawful today will suddenly become lawful tomorrow; in other words, the detention will suddenly become lawful. That is the very point which lies at the heart of our objection to this matter. It is not a matter of the substance of the legislation which is before us, but it is very much the haste with which this is being handled.

PARA.TAB: If we are successful in having this Committee report progress, I will be immediately moving that the whole matter be held over for at least seven sitting days so that there will be adequate time for people to look at this, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, for that court case to be held without the intrusion of this Committee having passed legislation which would virtually tie the hands of the judge who was hearing those cases. The point is the pre-empting nature of the action being taken now. It is the process that we are debating here, not the substance of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will firstly direct my remarks to the comments made by Senator Michael Baume and then I will ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) a question or two.

How long has the Committee had this matter in its hands? It has had this in its hands for 50 minutes. It will not alter the merit of the legislation, but it will certainly alter people's perception of the merit of the legislation. That brings me to the matter of the impact of the proposed legislation. Senator Baume asked whether these people who have applications before the Federal Court are in some way more significant than others? The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Hand, is opposing the applications. I ask Senator Bolkus, as the Minister representing Minister Hand in this chamber, whether the Government feels that the applications made by these people will be successful? It must feel that that will be the case or it would not be bringing in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just one of them might be successful.

—Yes, even one of them. Senator Baume referred to tax cases. The Parliament can make alterations to the tax laws, but if a tax case is on foot before the court, what happens then? Is it suggested that the new legislation would have some retrospective effect on the rights of a particular person? This is a similar situation in that a case is before the court. Applications have been made for release from detention. Presumably, it is argued that they are in detention illegally. It might be said by the Government that this legislation will not have an entirely retrospective effect; that once the Governor-General signs the Bill, it will have the prospective effect of retaining those persons in custody from that date. PARA.TAB: I now ask the Minister representing Minister Hand—I ask him this because he is a lawyer—whether he knows about the Torres Strait Islander case? That litigation, I remind the Committee, is not about property rights; it is about the rights to liberty under the rule of law. PARA.TAB: This illustrates the deep concern in the community regarding the way this Bill is being propelled through both the House of Representatives and this chamber at such a rate that it really casts the due consideration of the Senate in a bad light. TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening quite intently to the speakers in tonight's debate. I listened to Senator Harradine, as I generally do. I listened to Senator Coulter, to whom I generally do not listen. I listened to Senator Chamarette, and I read that same letter in my office only 10 minutes ago.

PARA.TAB: Let us get around to what Senator Coulter had to say in the first place. He said we should wait seven days because we have 22 people in custody in Port Hedland waiting for their case to come before the court. I would go along with that approach; it is a reasonable approach to take.

I unreservedly supported Senator Harradine on the 0055 matter because one has to draw the line somewhere. I am not a prude or anything like that, but one has to draw the line somewhere. The approach of Senator Coulter is to wait seven days. We can wait seven days, but what happens if another boat turns up in another seven days?

There has been something in the news lately that there is another boat on the way down from Indonesia. Maybe we will have a repeat—hopefully we will not—of the search that went on in the north west of WA last Christmas when 45, 46 or 56 people—whatever the figure was—walked across all that harsh country and, through good fortune, were all saved. Maybe something like that will happen on our doorstep again. If we give in and allow another seven days, there could be a boat in contact with Australia anyhow, because I believe someone is making some money out of dropping off these refugees. In another seven days we could be landed with another 22 refugees, and so it goes on. Just as I supported Senator Harradine on the 0055 matter because we had to set standards somewhere, I am afraid a standard has to be set now.

Australia, and Australia alone, controls its shorelines and who comes in—and who goes out in certain cases, too. What is more, we should make no apology to anyone in the rest of the world for controlling our own shorelines. Time and time again we have debated and questioned Ministers on the other side in Question Time about apologising to Asia or apologising to anyone. If we delay or change the legislation again because we are worried about what other countries might think of us, we are doing exactly the same thing—apologising to other countries for setting our own laws. That is something I will certainly not be part of.

This legislation should be passed immediately because far too many people have become involved in this debate on the refugees, whether they be in Port Hedland or Darwin, without knowing the full facts. There are a lot of do-gooders amongst them. I am not decrying the letter that Senator Chamarette read out. I suppose it is the job of those people to work on behalf of those refugees. But they are not the only ones; there have been others around Australia, from as far from Port Hedland as Sydney, who have had a lot to say on this matter. I wish that lot would have a lot more to say on fixing the legislation properly so we can control our shorelines.

I feel sympathy for any refugee, especially from Cambodia. But I believe that refugee status should be asked for in the first country one lands in. The 22 refugees at Port Hedland and those 57 or so who ended up in the Kimberleys last Christmas came via Indonesia. That is my bet anyhow. I think they should have asked for asylum in Indonesia.

Australia is a far better place in which to seek asylum with its open shores and good conditions. If these people are genuine refugees, I will be the first to welcome them. However, I believe that the courts should process it in an orderly fashion. If they are refugees, then Australia will take them, but if they are not they should be put on the next plane back. It is time we got on to this immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again it has become necessary to clearly distinguish what this chamber is debating tonight. There is no argument about the views put forward by Senator Panizza. Of course we should take steps to guard our shore line and of course Australia should be in control of who enters this country and how and when they enter it. There is absolutely no argument about it. What is at issue is whether we should interfere in a court case which is being held to decide whether people should be detained, and whether they should stay in this country or go.

PARA.TAB: The simple question is whether this country is still subject to a rule of law or whether it is subject to the machinations of some politicians who believe that they have the right to intervene in the legal processes which guard the civil rights of citizens. I remind honourable senators once again of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which refers to `anyone' who is deprived of his liberty. It does not say a Cambodian citizen who is deprived of his or her liberty. It does not say an Australian who is deprived or his or her liberty. It sets up a general principle. It says that anyone who is deprived of his or her liberty has a right to due process at law. This chamber is about to intervene in the due process of law. We will rue the day if we allow it to proceed in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I come back to the unanswered question, I wish to refer to something that Senator Panizza said. Senator Panizza referred to the merit of the legislation. I indicated to Senator Baume that whether or not this was deferred would, in fact, affect people's perception of the merit. I would like to have time to talk with Senator Panizza—for whom I have a great deal of respect—about the Italians who were detained during the war and whether, in fact, they should have been detained in the way that they were detained during the war, and whether or not their human rights were properly protected during the war.

—Exactly. As Senator Baume has said, they were urgency powers. There is no comparison between what powers were required during the war and what powers are required now. PARA.TAB: I would like the Minister to respond to the question that I asked and I also ask him another question. On page 2 of the amendments that have been sent to us by the House of Representatives, interpretation 54K defines a designated person as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a non-citizen who:
(a) has been on a boat in the territorial sea of Australia after 19 December 1989 and before 1 December 1992;. . .
What is the reason for those two dates?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting that Senator Harradine should bring up the case of the Italians. Honourable senators may remember that in this chamber some two years ago I put through a motion of reconciliation for those who were locked up during the time that Italy was part of the war. Senator Baume said that they were locked up under emergency powers, for emergency reasons. There is a difference in that the Italians had no chance to put their case to a court. They had no chance to put it in front of a tribunal.

PARA.TAB: I have been doing quite a bit of study into this matter since I put that motion through. My colleague Dr Woods put it through the House of Representatives. Old files that have been subject to the 40- and 50-year limitations are now emerging and I am able to look at them in the Archives. Those people were accused, not face to face, but just by a letter or a telephone call. The emergency people took them and that was it. They never had a chance.
Unless I am mightily wrong, if this legislation goes through as it is tonight, these refugees will appear in front of the court on Thursday. Is that right?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.
—The judge's hands are tied.

—In Senator Spindler's opinion, the judge's hands are tied, but they will appear in front of the court. The case of the Italians was vastly different because they had no recourse to law at the time. They just had to bide their time until commonsense prevailed and they were let out. I reiterate everything I have already said. We have to be in control of what goes on in Australia and not apologise for it. I thank Senator Harradine for making the comparison he made, but I think there is a difference.

—I, too, would like to address a question to the Minister. This Bill appears to repudiate Australia's obligations in the areas of human rights and refugee rights under various United Nations instruments to which we are signatories. It would seem that these people are having their right of habeas corpus removed after they have already spent two years in custody. They need their day and for the court to be able to act in their regard. That is just by way of response to Senator Panizza.

PARA.TAB: The Minister, after recently acknowledging that the applications for refugee status had been bungled, agreed to a review of the cases, but is now seeking by this legislation to short-circuit any meaningful review by legislating these people out of sight. Why is the Government using such a heavy approach to this group? After all, it made special provision for a great number of Chinese students after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and has special entry provision for people from Sri Lanka. Why is the Government seeking to make conditions more punitive and more distressing for people who have left their home country with nothing or next to nothing, often in fear of their lives, than it does for people who come on a visitor's visa and choose to overstay and then apply for residency? I would like a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think most contributions were assertions and debate. As to Senator Harradine's first question, I will not make any assessment as to the viability or otherwise of the case, and nor should I. As to the second question relating to the dates, the first date of 19 November 1989 refers to the date of the arrival of a boat at Pinda Bay. That framework has been referred to in the Minister's second reading speech.

I feel that I have to reply to the last point. It is the simplest thing in this debate to be populist—to come in here charged with emotion and not with facts. It is the simplest thing in this debate to colour this subject. What Senator Chamarette has to understand is that there are a hell of a lot of people who want to come to this country. We have had for quite a number of years an orderly migration program. As part of that program, there are different categories. People wait for a long time to come to Australia.

We are talking here about people who claim to be refugees. If their claims are proven to be valid and they are defined and interpreted by the courts as refugees, then they have rights to stay here. But until that is the case, they are to be treated in the same way as any other person seeking entry into Australia—and that is what this proposed legislation does. I think it probably best that we now move to the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has talked about people coming in here and speaking emotionally. I take some exception to that. I suppose one is entitled to get a bit emotional about the issue of human rights—
—And justice.

—Yes, and justice. I did ask the Minister a specific question about the Torres Strait Islander case, which involved the Queensland Government. If the Minister does not know the case himself, he should get some of his advisers to advise him about it. I asked the Minister how the action of the current Government—his Government—differs from that taken by the Queensland Government in 1985. That action was described by the High Court as `draconian' in that it purported to defeat the litigation that was pending in the High Court in reference to property rights. I repeat that we are not dealing with property rights here; we are dealing with the rights to liberty under the rule of law.
—I answered this particular point at the start of the debate.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—Senator Coulter, it may be appropriate for you to move your motion now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I formally put the motion, I would like to bring the Committee back to the very simple single point, because most honourable senators have strayed away from it. They have talked about the substance of the Migration Amendment Bill; they have talked about the amendments themselves; they have talked about all sorts of other things. For example, Senator Panizza talked about Australia having rights over who does and who does not come into the country, whether or not we need to guard our shores and whether we have rights in those respects—with all of which one can wholeheartedly agree.

PARA.TAB: There is just one single very simple point that causes me to move that progress be reported at this stage so that we can then have a longer period of consideration of this legislation; that is, that there is a case that will come before the courts on Thursday. That case does not go to the matter of whether these people are refugees. It goes to the matter of whether these people shall remain in custody.

The amendments, if passed tonight, will tie the hands of the judge to the extent that he or she will be prevented from allowing that person to be released from custody—even if on all the merits of the case that judge thinks that that person should be released. The single important point which I believe lies very much at the heart of what we mean by justice is that the rules should not be changed midstream. A case will be coming before the courts on Thursday. In the consideration of the evidence in that court, this legislation which we are asked to pass tonight will change the rules and tie the hands of the judge. Irrespective of the merits of the case, those people, or one person who may have a legitimate case to be released from custody, will not be able to be released because the judge will be prevented from giving a judgment in accordance with the facts.

That is the simple matter which I am putting to the Committee of the Whole at this stage. I have been disappointed to hear that so many of my colleagues in this place do not understand that very simple point. It is an extremely simple point. Everybody should be able to understand that we should not change the rules midstream.

TALK.START.PARA: —The stream is ever flowing; there is always an immigration matter before the court.

—The stream is ever flowing. If we were to consider this legislation in three weeks time and bring it in so that it became active in a further week or so after that, I would have no objection to it at all.
—What about the next boat?

—There is no problem with that; that could be caught up with these things when this legislation is passed. It has nothing to do with the next boat or when it gets here; people have a matter before the court and the Government is wanting to change the rules, to tie the hands of the judge. It is as simple as that.

PARA.TAB: I refer again to the International Covenant of Civil Rights and whether a detention is unlawful. What may be unlawful at the moment—let us not prejudge it—we are seeking to make lawful simply to close the opportunity in relation to a case which is already before the court. I think that is reprehensible. Accordingly, I hope that all honourable senators of conscience will support me as I move:
That progress be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Beginning this list of amendments is clause 54J, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This Division is enacted because the Parliament considers that it is in the national interest that each non-citizen who is a designated person should be kept in custody until he or she:

PARA.TAB: (a) leaves Australia; or
(b) is given an entry permit.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask the Minister about this clause. It is somewhat strange to have a descriptive reason given in a piece of legislation like this, but, leaving that aside, the definition of `designated person' further down under clause 54K is given as:
. . . a non-citizen who:

PARA.TAB: (a)has been on a boat in the territorial sea of Australia after 19 November 1989 and before 1 December 1992; and
(b)has not presented a visa; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I was smiling, but I was smiling at the inability of the Minister to grasp the logic of what I was saying. The subclauses in clause 54K are separated by the conjunction `and'. PARA.TAB: I ask again: why is this so narrowly drawn? If those people, who in every other respect are in Australia without a visa or an entry permit, should be kept separate—and I presume that they should be if clause 54J means anything at all—why is it so narrowly drawn? It is just a simple point of logic. That is why I was smiling.

—I refer to the meaning of `custody' in these amendments. Within the meaning of section 11 of the Act, `custody' includes being held in a processing centre. Section 11 of the Act includes in the definition of `custody' a person being held in another place approved by the Minister in writing.

PARA.TAB: In the current circumstances an offer has been made by the charitable organisations and religious bodies to house these particular persons, some of whom, I remind the chamber, have been in detention since November 1989 and have suffered considerable stress as a result thereof. The Minister does not want me to table what the Human Rights Commission says about it. I will accede to his request, but I know and he knows that considerable stress and distress have been caused as a result of the long detention of some of these people. TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I will be making only a small contribution to tonight's debate on the amendment that has come from the other place. It was my intention to make a more substantial submission in support of the action by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) in bringing this legislation before the House. This is crucial legislation. It does not only impact on 27 people; it has an impact on the whole of Australia's refugee program. In the past couple of years that refugee program has been abused and brought into disrepute by the actions of a number of individuals—not only those detained in custody. A number of people—some with goodwill and others, I would suggest, with different motives—have sought to abuse the privilege of refugee status that Australia, as a nation state, can give to people.

PARA.TAB: As has been mentioned on a number of occasions, some people have been interned in holding camps in Australia for a considerable length of time. It is not the fault of the Government, the Minister or the Department that those people have been confined for so long. Indeed, in some cases, it is the fault of the individual; in some cases it is the fault of the legal advisers that those people have engaged. They were not properly advised and sought to abuse the circumstances in which they found themselves by remaining in Australia—albeit in some form of custody—in the hope that at some later time they could mount the argument that, because they had been in Australia so long, they should be granted refugee status or some other form of permanent residency and so be allowed to stay.

Every time a concession is made on a matter of immigration policy—and this happens in other areas of government administration—abuses occur. In this particular area we have seen a number of abuses. There are not only 27 people in custody at the present time; there are over 450 people—illegal entrants to this country—in custody. I believe that if they are given refugee status by whatever means—be it through the courts or by some other means—the floodgates will open and many more boats will appear on the northern and western shores of this country carrying people who believe they have a claim for refugee status.

This is a very serious problem that must be addressed now. If it is not addressed now, it will be much more difficult to address when there are 4,500 people in detention, or when there are 45,000, because it is not unreasonable to suspect that the number might grow tenfold. It is an almighty dilemma that the Government is facing, and I believe that the Minister is acting quite properly in this matter. He is also acting under a fair degree of pressure. Earlier this year he admitted publicly in a very candid statement that he had been taken for a dill by some people. It is not too often that a Minister of the Crown is quite as frank and honest as that. He certainly was frank with the Australian community and I believe that the Australian community appreciated that frankness because it too is concerned about any potential problem that might be down the line.

It has been suggested in some of the submissions made here tonight that this amendment is interfering with these people's rights to make an appeal following an application for refugee status. That application for appeal against an administrative decision of the Department can and, indeed, will proceed at the will of the Court.
