SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has not dealt in substance with this Bill yet. I should like to place on record our position on this amendment to Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) of 1991. We believe that this amendment is a necessary amendment to that Bill.

PARA.TAB: As the Senate is aware, presently there are some 389 boat people in detention around Australia under the current provisions of the Migration Act and another vessel carrying 10 people is expected to arrive in Australia soon. Under the current provisions of the Migration Act, it is possible that the courts can release these people into the community. It is our very strong view that this should not be possible. Thirty-seven detainees are in the process of challenging the rejection of their claims and will be in court from 7 May to argue for their release from custody. This legislation provides—as an interim measure only—new custody arrangements which will deny courts the power to release boat people into the community. This legislation would have to be passed through the Senate today to enable it to receive the Governor-General's assent before the court case to release the 37 detainees begins.

People who arrive in Australia illegally are held in custody pending the determination of any claims they may make for refugee status. Current detainees are in section 88 custody which pertains to those who have been arrested at sea in territorial waters and brought ashore by Australian authorities as prohibited immigrants, or in section 92 custody which pertains to those who landed as illegal entrants. This distinction between persons who are arrested before disembarking from a boat and persons who arrive by boat and enter undetected is a major weakness of the Act and is the subject of challenge by a further three detainees who arrived on the last boat.

In other words, the simple distinction is whether or not they are prohibited entrants or illegal entrants. These are the people we are discussing. Are they prohibited or illegal? Neither category of entrant has proper title to the term `Australian resident'. This matter should be looked at in terms of equity and fairness. They have jumped the queue and are either prohibited or illegal entrants.

On 7 May, 37 section 88 detainees will challenge the rejection of their claims and ask to be released from custody. The new legislation is proposed to guarantee continued custody by providing a common custody regime for all boat people, whether they are in section 88 or section 92 custody. This will apply to all arrivals after 28 November 1989 and before 1 November 1992. The legislation will provide for a period of nine months detention for all current detainees to commence when the proposed legislation receives royal assent.

Under the legislation for any future arrival a period of nine months detention is to commence on the date that an application for refugee status or other claim is submitted to immigration officials. Current provisions require a claim to be submitted within two months of arrival. If no submission is received within that period, the Act provides for the removal of that person from Australia. Future arrivals will be subject to immediate custody under the new provisions when they arrive in Australia and the nine months will not commence until they lodge an application. The nine-month `clock' will stop when it is necessary to obtain information or expert evidence to properly process a claim, or where a claim is subject to litigation. In effect, this can lead to exceptionally long detention periods, particularly if a case is taken through all levels of appeal.

The new legislation will provide to the extent possible that a court cannot release persons who are in custody under the new arrangements. An appeal to the High Court on habeas corpus will be unlikely to succeed, since the custody arrangements are legal. However, it does not interfere with the High Court's original jurisdiction. The legislation will provide for the removal of detainees whose claims to remain in Australia are rejected and allow them to continue to be held in custody pending the finalisation of removal arrangements. We must recognise that this legislation is very tough and will not be unchallenged by a variety of interest groups, including the law councils, the Refugee Council and civil liberty groups. However, it is necessary, fair and equitable to the Australian people.

It should be noted, too, that it is intended only as an interim measure to deal with a particular issue. The Minister intends to introduce comprehensive new entry removal and custody provisions into the Migration Act in the Budget session and hopes to have them in place by the expiry of this legislation on 1 November 1992.

There is a strong need for these interim measures and subsequent revision of the Migration Act. The current powers in the Act to arrest and detain persons without authority to enter or remain in Australia are cumbersome, outdated and in places silent on important issues such as re-arrest. A major weakness is the spurious distinction between persons who are arrested before disembarking from a boat and persons who arrive by boat and enter undetected.

As I mentioned earlier, the former are prohibited entrants under section 88 and the latter are illegal entrants under section 92. This distinction affected the detention of the people who arrived on the last boat, that is, the 56 PRC nationals, as under section 92 each had to be the subject of a separate court order. There are three people in the group presently challenging the continuation of their custody who allege that they had entered Australia and, therefore, were improperly held under section 88.

If this legislation is not passed, the possibility that all detainees could be released into the community exposes Australia to the risk of a much larger influx of people. If these people were classed as refugees, they would be admitted—and Senator Chamarette can put her bottom jaw back into position. Our obligations to offer protection to genuine refugees as defined by the United Nations Convention and protocols is not affected by this legislation. It is designed to prevent abuse. Because of the strict provisions for legal migration in our migration program, migrants are increasingly trying to enter through the narrow window left open to grant asylum to political refugees.

Developed countries have seen a 700 per cent increase in asylum claims over the last decade. Australia itself has witnessed an increase from 500 claims a year a few years ago to over 23,000. Although having no land borders and thus not subject to the enormous pressures being placed on borders in western Europe, Australia's geography and regional environment make it particularly vulnerable to boat arrivals. The journey from Asia involves only a fortnight's sailing and little serious danger.

Once released into the community, location and removal are extremely difficult and, I might add, very costly to the Australian taxpayer. Where boat arrivals are motivated not by fear of persecution but by a simple desire to migrate, release from custody achieves de facto migration and sends a signal to others planning to follow the same route. This is an essential element of our determination to support this legislation.
As I said earlier, this Bill has been moved as an amendment to the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4). We took the view that that Bill should have a second reading amendment in the following terms:

That, while not denying the Bill a second reading, the Opposition deplores the Government's failure to reconstruct the immigration program to more accurately reflect the current needs of the national economy and to deliver a program that is in the long term interests of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, however, that this amendment is in the best interests of the Australian people. For that reason, the Opposition supports it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise briefly the matter of the Australian air traffic control system contract, which has been a matter of great concern for the Senate ever since its inception. I am prompted to do that by the incredible evidence that has been put on the public record in the last two hearings of the Joint Committee on Public Works on 8 April and 27 April. I commend a reading of those Hansards to all honourable senators. I think most people reading the evidence given would come to the conclusion that what we are witnessing here is probably the abuse of the public interest by a public monopoly.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee was set up under an Act of this Parliament to look at the expenditure of funds beyond a certain level for public works. Essentially, what the Public Works Committee was looking into here was a request by the Civil Aviation Authority to provide it with a blank cheque for up to $50m to build two building complexes—one in Brisbane and one in Melbourne. The CAA gave very little justification for this and virtually no detail. The matter of accountability in this contract is of great parliamentary concern and it is a matter of great concern to the Senate and to the Public Works Committee. It goes right to the heart of public administration as we know it in this country.

To put this matter in context, I will very briefly give an account of the air traffic control systems that exist in this country. They basically consist of a series of radar stations and the linking of ground stations to those radar stations so that information on air traffic can be provided. We have two very run-down facilities at Brisbane and Sydney, as is well referenced by the press accounts.

The facilities at Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne were replaced in the recent past by the ATCARDS program, and we have had adequate publicity about the failures of the tender and of Thomson-CSF to fulfil the contract in an efficient and professional way. Since the ATCARDS program we have had the RASPP program with Cairns, Coolangatta, Mount Gellibrand and Mount Macedon. Part of that program is still in train. Again, we have had performance problems with the contractor who again was Thomson.

The RADREP proposal had been put forward to replace the facilities in both Brisbane and Sydney. That had gone to tender when the Civil Aviation Authority appointed a new Chief Executive Officer, Mr Baldwin from New Zealand. He came in, threw the program out and instituted the TAAATS which is the program we are talking about now. This matter was analysed in part in the Public Works Committee hearings.

In essence, Mr Baldwin instituted a new program for Australia without any cost analysis, without any design development or anything to justify the system. He just said, `We are going to have this' and proceeded to go through the selection process to bring this about. I do not wish to waste the time of the Senate by going through the shortcomings of the approach in selecting the type of management system proposed for air traffic control, nor by commenting on the difficulties of the hands off, turnkey approach which is also an inherent part of the system that is being proposed in this case. I again advise honourable senators to read their Hansards for the details of this.

I will now deal briefly with the concerns we have had with the program. My initial concern was when, in May 1991, only six companies were invited to tender and no Australian companies were allowed to tender for the system. This was an arrogant, unwarranted and indefensible assumption by the CAA that no company in Australia could do it. Only a month before, in April 1991, the Government had signed the tender for the JON program—Jindalee over-the-horizon radar. The tender cost was $1,053m at April 1991 prices—something like four or five times the cost of the civil aviation program. It was a high risk program; there is much original and creative research in it. But the Department of Defence which was letting the contract had no inhibitions at all about allowing Australian companies to tender. It is a matter of record that two Australian companies—AWA and Telecom—were the finalists and the tender was awarded to Telecom.

The question I ask the Senate is: how can we grow as a nation if we do not treat our Australian companies as equals in the area of commercial contracts like this? The tender process that we have developed will sort out the inadequacies of those companies, but it is absolutely outrageous that Australian companies can be debarred from tendering for something like this relatively simple CAA contract. That was my primary concern, which was shared by most of the members of the Senate.

The second concern that was raised in the Senate was when, in late March 1992, it was announced that Thomson was the preferred tenderer. The concern was about the very low Australian industry participation that goes with the Thomson bid, and it flew in the face of established government policy.

Again, it is a matter of public record that there was a bitter row with Senator Button, Mr Beazley and Senator Bolkus, Ministers who represented the three departments, who were outraged with the way the contract had been given to Thomson, in the face of higher Australian industry involvement by other companies. The Government is not using a crude argument. It must be understood that it is not a simple argument saying: we want so and so to win this contract so that Australian companies can have a share on one occasion to fulfil this contract. It is a very sophisticated argument and it is aimed at developing Australian industry, not under one contract but for long term participation in world markets.

If we look at Thomson's record—I will leave aside its technical inadequacies and deal with those in a few minutes—we will see that it has contributed nothing to the body corporate of Australia in the work it has done. It has moved through with its contracts like a plague of locusts, leaving nothing behind. It has not honoured the offset agreements that it entered into in the past. On one occasion, I am advised, it had to be forgiven by the Government because it had not fulfilled one of its offset obligations.

It is not an Australian company. It is only a shell company of a French company. Adding insult to injury in this case, there was a $50m civil works program for these buildings which the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works inquired into. Apparently Thomson proposes to do that with a company called Beca, which is a New Zealand company. It is a shell company with no Australian substance to it at all. The final insult to injury is that it will use Beca, if it finally gets the contract, to satisfy offset requirements of the New Zealand Government for a New Zealand contract.

The other finalist was Hughes, which has a very good record of Australian industry participation. It has written over $1 billion worth of work in Australia in the past 10 years. Not only has it entered into offset agreements and honoured every one of them, but also it is proposing to have a partnership agreement with its Australian associates—BHP, AWA and the Bassett group—to go on and tender for worldwide contracts. As I say, the record of Hughes has been absolutely exemplary in fulfilling its offset requirements in Australia.

AWA was one of the companies associated with it. AWA has developed a voice switching apparatus for the air traffic control system. It has been a high cost, high value R&D program. It is a quite good switch. AWA is looking for worldwide markets for this. I am advised that at the present time reports are coming back from Austrade in our embassy in Beijing that the Chinese Government, which is one of AWA's targets for buying this voice switching gear, is concerned that it did not win the contract on this occasion.

It is very difficult for a company to market its products abroad if its own country has no confidence in it. AWA at present is tendering for somewhere in excess of $120m worth of aerospace equipment around the world. It has had a very heavy censure placed on it by not being selected with Hughes on this contract. While we cannot accept that in isolation as justification for the awarding of a contract, it is one of the things that has to be considered. Of course, that is why Senator Button, Senator Bolkus and Mr Beazley were so furious about what happened.

The major concern that the Senate has with the latest CAA contract gets to accountability. This Parliament does have to account for the expenditure of public funds. Of course, that is the concern of the Public Works Committee hearings. I stress that this is not a party political matter. If honourable senators read the report, listen to the comments in the chamber and read the Hansard records of the inquiries of the Public Works Committee, they will see that this has unanimous support across the Committee. There is no division along party lines in questioning the CAA. However, there is a real concern about this matter of parliamentary accountability.

I must say that in Australia we do have a system of assessing tender documents and selecting equipment in a way that is transparent and allows accountability to take place. We might end up with the wrong decision on some occasions, but there is never any criticism that somewhere or other malpractice has taken place along the way. I am at a loss to understand why the Civil Aviation Authority has on this occasion adopted the practices of a Third World country or a totalitarian regime.

I return to the beginning of this matter. In May 1991 six companies were invited to tender. Mr Baldwin said that he knew who to invite, and he invited six companies. In the end only four responded. That raises serious questions about Mr Baldwin's knowledge and judgment of the industry. From there we moved to the selection process. As I said earlier, we have a set procedure for this. Following a series of public notices, we move through various stages until we come to a final decision. On this occasion the procedure set by Senator Bolkus's Department, the Department of Administrative Services—the calling of tenders—was not followed. The reason given by Mr Baldwin was that all this was far too complex—it could not be done in this case; one could not simply write a specification and go to tender through the normal practices.

We do call tenders on some very complex things and some very high cost equipment in this country. The tender procedures are flexible enough to allow that to be done. At the end of the day it is rubbish to say that an air traffic control system cannot be tendered for through the accepted Australian procedures. An air traffic control system collects data in one sphere and processes it in another. There are no real unknowns in that. There are certainly a few difficulties in putting the thing together. Some companies such as Thomson-CSF never seem to get it right anywhere in the world. Most major companies such as Siemens Plessey, Hughes and Raytheon can. It is quite possible to write a specific tender for this situation. Without a tender it is very hard to fairly judge the competitive claims of people who are tendering to supply the system.

The assessment has to be fair not only to satisfy the principal requirement, which is to establish that the interests of the Australian taxpayer have been met, but also to satisfy the companies themselves. On a contract like this they would spend somewhere between $600,000 and $700,000 in preparing a tender. They are entitled to a professional assessment of their bid.

In my time in parliament we faced contracts for Defence that go right to the limit of technology, including the new tactical fighter when the FA-18 was bought, the Collins submarines and the Anzac ships. They involved billions of dollars, as against millions of dollars in this case. They are highly technical, on the fringe of technology. In all of them tender documents and stages were prepared and followed. There was never any suspicion that any malpractice took place anywhere along the line.

As part of the assessment process in this instance, five assessment groups were set up. They were pretty broadly based. They had 25 air traffic controllers spread across the five groups, 25 engineers and technical people. They looked at the operational requirements, the technical side of it, the civil works, the finance, life cycle costs and project management. They made their assessment.

The first company to miss out was Siemens Plessey, which in some ways was the front runner. It had a proven system off the shelf and was probably the cheapest. It was removed on the specious grounds, which I went through in this chamber some while ago, of having a high risk program for its flight data processing. That left Hughes, IBM and Thomson in the deal. The five evaluation groups that I have referred to all selected Hughes on every count.

In November 1991 Hughes, IBM and Thomson were asked by letter for their final bid. Traditionally, when a company gets a request for a final bid on a contract, that is the end. It is the final price, the deal is over and everything is considered on that point. Hughes and IBM proceeded on the basis that this was the end. They made their bid, to be told, to their surprise, by Mr Baldwin—or his mouthpiece, Dr Edwards—on 20 December 1991 that the selection system had now changed and a decision would be made in March 1992. At this time Hughes was clearly ahead. The evaluation teams had all selected it. Its price was somewhere around $90m less and it was 11 months quicker to fulfil its contract. Despite all that, the CAA claimed that it was all too close to judge.

The CAA sought time through deferment so that the goalposts could be changed and the bids could be altered by Thomson to make them competitive with Hughes. One of the things that the CAA did was to go to Hughes and say, `Look, your contract time is unacceptable to us; you must extend it by six months on the completion stage and by a further five months on the test and transition stage', which Hughes did. That made Hughes the same as Thomson.

The next thing was that it said it required performance guarantees, and that added $12m to the Hughes' price. Surprise, surprise! The Thomson price came down $15m, although there were higher costs involved in providing the guarantees. I will not go through the allegations of the changes to the ROI rules that are instanced in the Hansards of the Public Works Committee except that they provide an insight into the looseness of the management practices followed by the CAA at the time.

Another of the significant points made in the Hansards of the Public Works Committee is a very serious allegation as to the integrity of security of information held by the CAA. The allegations are made there that Thomson was aware continually of whatever Hughes' position was as a competing tenderer. While that was not resolved, there are enough questions raised there that demand an answer in due course.

The reasons for the preferment given by the CAA were that Hughes essentially was a much higher risk and that Thomson had delivered more air traffic control systems around the world. The CAA did claim that the Australian industry participation was the same; a claim that was rejected very strenuously by DITAC later when it came out and said that Hughes was at least 20 per cent better.

The first general observation I make is that Thomson-CSF does not have an international reputation for quality in the air traffic control field. In fact, there is an organisation of authorities that has been formed around the world who are users of Thomson equipment and who are so dissatisfied with the performance of that equipment that they are wanting to band together. They have had a history of failures with the ATCARDS, the RASPP and other programs not only in Australia but also in countries like Belgium, Denmark, Finland and Czechoslovakia.

The claim that Hughes is a high risk company is not supported by fact. It does have a much better system of coping with flight data processing as well as the radar data processing than Thomson. The importance of that is that something like 10 per cent of Australia's air space will be covered by radar and 90 per cent will be not covered, and that 90 per cent which is not covered is the flight data processing which comes from flight plans. It has to be integrated into the display system and the presentation, and that requires a very sophisticated software program.

The Thomson system, based on a European system, is basically using radar data processing from radar sensors, and the integration problems there are quite formidable. I do not wish tonight to go through the arguments about the program being written in ADA as opposed to the Jovial language that some of the Hughes programs are written in beyond saying that the software component in the data processing is only about one per cent of the contract and Hughes gave guarantees that they would be fully in ADA by that time.

What has emerged from all of this is that we have a totally unacceptable selection system; a system, I would say, that on any reading of the Public Works Committee Hansards is totally unacceptable and discredited. What happened was that there was clearly no selection pathway before it started. Quite clearly, both the goalposts and the finishing post were moved through the contract. People who criticised Thomson were removed. People who supported Thomson—namely, Baldwin and Edwards—became the people who did it all, who made the selection.

It is interesting to look at what people say about this. The Civil Air Organisation—the air traffic controllers—withdrew from the selection process. I would like to read from one of its letters given to the Public Works Committee. In a letter of 29 February to Mr Baldwin, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is with deep regret that I advise the CAA of the withdrawal of Civil Air from the evaluation of the TAAATS project tenders. The reason for withdrawal is because of the lack of fairness demonstrated by CAA management in this process.

I suspect that the word `fairness' is selected because, in the jargon that we used in clinics when writing up patients' records, it is not actionable. I wonder whether the Civil Air operators really mean that the system is not honest when they talk about `fairness'.

PARA.TAB: There were protests to the Public Works Committee about the selection process from the Royal Australian Institute of Architects, the Metal and Engineering Workers Union, the Association of Professional Engineers and Scientists of Australia, from Siemens Plessey and from Hughes itself. In the light of all that criticism, we have to seriously consider whether the selection process that took place was adequate.

So much for the procedures; what about the price of the contract? The best information I have is that the initial bid from Hughes was $190m and that from Thomson $280m. When it came down to the November 1991 bid, Hughes lowered its bid to $140m and Thomson came down to $185m. In March 1992, when the selection was made, I estimate that the Hughes bid was around $150m and the Thomson bid was around $160m to $165m. There was always a very significant price difference between the two bids.

In conclusion, I refer to one very important point, and that is the place of the board of the Civil Aviation Authority. It is very clear that the whole program was driven by Mr Baldwin, the Chief Executive Officer, and that all the advice that went to the board of the Civil Aviation Authority was filtered through Mr Baldwin's hands. This Parliament needs to see the reports made by the five evaluation committees back in November 1991, which all favoured Hughes, and compare them with the advice that was given to the board by Mr Baldwin at the same time. We need to see how well informed the board was.

The directors of the Civil Aviation Authority must recognise that they bear a very serious responsibility. Directors' duties certainly are onerous these days but their obligations—even though they are in a government business enterprise—are exactly the same as those of the executives of any other commercial company. It might be that in the past they have worked in a low-key way, free from controversy, but the commercial law of Australia applies to them as it applies to the directors of any other company. They must protect their shareholders' interests; they have a fiduciary duty. It seems that they have failed to exercise the care and caution which is incumbent on them to satisfy themselves.

The board of the Civil Aviation Authority is not endowed with any inherent technical expertise. Apparently, it accepted Mr Baldwin's advice without ever seeking any independent assessment of it. Two audits were performed, but they were performed at the direction of Mr Baldwin. There was no independent assessment of the advice that was given them. My advice to the directors of the Civil Aviation Authority is that not only are they in precisely the same position as directors of any other commercial company, they should also take very careful note of what is now happening to the directors of Compass. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Battle of the Coral Sea: Commemoration

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a speech on the adjournment debate which I was going to make last night, but I decided not to make it this morning, and I hope I will be finished by tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, prior to the point at which Senator Newman sought to have motion 829 relating to the 50th anniversary of the battle of the Coral Sea standing in her name declared formal, she kindly brought it to my notice. This presented me with the dilemma of being a lone senator who could oppose the motion being taken as formal.

I say `dilemma' because I found the sentiments and assumptions within the motion antithetical not only to my views but also, more importantly, to the concerns of the voters whom I represent in this place. Nevertheless, I felt that it would be discourteous and disrespectful to the majority view of this Senate to place myself at odds with it. I choose to retain the option of opposing the majority view on matters which cause me a much greater level of disagreement or disquiet than the matter raised by Senator Newman. However, I feel the need to express my qualifications regarding Senator Newman's motion from the point of view of the Greens and the many members of the peace and social justice movements within the community.

Many people feel that the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea is not simply a memorial to the tragic and wasteful loss of human lives, but is an opportunity of glorifying war and the promotion of military power to control and suppress, rather than the power of mediation, negotiation and diplomacy.

The fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea should be used as a time of sober reflection on the futility of war. When we look back, yes, we can say that Australia's well-being was served and, yes, we can say that many firm personal relationships were forged. But we also have to look at the overall consequences. Thousands of lives were lost; extraordinary damage was done which cost millions of dollars; and now, 50 years on, the world situation is such that anything which looks remotely like a glorification of war can be regarded only as obscene.

The US Congress paid tribute to the US-Australia relationship, and we would welcome such a tribute if, and only if, the US Congress recognises that the relationship is one of equals in which neither party can call the shots; a relationship in which one party does not have to slavishly follow the other, whether it be in matters cultural, economic or military. I concur with the reservations about the equality of the relationship expressed in Senator Spindler's notice of motion 841.

The US Congress recognised the ANZUS treaty, and we would want to say that the treaty, particularly in recent years, has been the means by which the US and, to some extent, our own country has sought to bully New Zealand, the third party to the treaty, into acting against what it sees as its own best interest. This is not the behaviour of a friend or genuine ally. The New Zealand decision against nuclear warships was translated into a boycott of the entire defence relationship, including intelligence exchange. Allies do not make or break relations according to differences which are stated in mature and rational terms. Is this the sort of treaty and friendship that we want to honour and promote; one in which the powerful members bully the less powerful; a friendship based on military expediency?

We would also want to say that the extraordinary degree of cooperation noted in Senator Newman's motion did not apparently extend to the US informing the Australian public of the use of the joint bases in Australia to monitor Scud missile firings during the Gulf war, in spite of the Hawke Government's utmost readiness to support the US in its initiative in that conflict. Indeed, as Mr Ted Lindsay pointed out in the House of Representatives last week, the degree of information available, even to Australian parliamentarians, about the nature of the joint defence facilities is less than that available to the American public. Indeed, Mr Lindsay pointed out that the briefing offered to members of the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, FADT, was an unclassified one and that material readily available to the public in the US was not made available to members of the subcommittee. So much for the extraordinarily close friendship which Senator Newman's motion claims we share with the US!

There is one aspect of Senator Newman's motion which would have our support, and that is the portion which calls upon the US Congress to implement its trading policies so that Australian farmers are not disadvantaged. It is a strange friendship where one party actively undermines the well-being of the other while claiming not to.

Finally, let us entertain adult equal relationships with governments throughout the world which demonstrate integrity and respect and, within that, can handle a diversity of views rather than forming them-and-us relationships which buy or placate allies on the basis of military strength.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave notice of a motion concerning the retirement of Mr Jim Bell, AM, who this Friday retires as Chairman of the Australian Jockey Club after nine years at the helm. During the years that Jim has been Chairman I have come to know him well and on many occasions I have partaken of his hospitality—and I did so last Saturday. I have also had occasion to meet with him in my role as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. As honourable senators would be aware, the Senate undertook an inquiry into the racing industry and the AJC was represented at those hearings.

PARA.TAB: Jim Bell's interest in racing and racehorses goes back a long way. He started his active interest in racing in the south of the State and was a member of the South East Racing Association which controls racing in this area. He was involved on that committee from 1968 to 1977 and, for most of that time, was also Chairman of the Goulburn Race Club.

He was first elected to the AJC committee in 1977, became Vice-Chairman in 1980 and Chairman in 1983. During the time of his chairmanship he has also been Chairman of the Australian Conference of Principal Racing Clubs at biannual meetings at Sydney, alternating with the VRC Chairman. The Australian Conference of Principal Racing Clubs is the controlling body of racing in Australia—an industry which, by any measure, is a significant contributor to the economy. I believe it is the third largest industry in Australia.

Anyone who has been to Randwick racecourse cannot help but be impressed by its magnificence. It is truly Royal Randwick and on a spring or autumn day there is nothing quite so splendid as that racecourse. Jim Bell's contribution as Chairman has clearly been evident in the number of improvements made to Randwick and to racing over the years. The increase in drug testing and the effectiveness of it through the new facilities at Randwick is one such indicator, as is the new $30m grandstand which was opened in February this year by Her Majesty the Queen—which definitely made the racecourse Royal Randwick. I looked over that grandstand last Saturday with Mr Tony Allport, a member of the committee, and Mr Bill Rutledge, and no doubt the Australian Jockey Club in Sydney has made sure that the ordinary punter who goes to the races to enjoy a day out and see the magnificent horses racing can do it in a comfort which is now even greater than the comfort experienced by the members of the AJC.

In addition, the equine swimming pool at the Randwick racecourse has been completed. That is another achievement for Jim Bell. He has also been a great supporter of the stewards that control racing, and I know they respect him greatly. The Chairman of the Stipendiary Stewards, John Schreck, and the Chief Veterinary Surgeon, Craig Suann, have both been fully supported by Mr Bell in his endeavours to make racing in New South Wales and Australia better than anywhere else in the world.

Having been involved in the Goulburn Race Club for so many years, Jim is concerned about the financial problems facing country race clubs. Over the years he has been a great visitor to country clubs and I know that quite often he has visited the show course of the north in northern New South Wales—my home race club of Quirindi. In addition, he has visited other race clubs such as the Tamworth race club where a turnover of $1m is commonplace. Last year on a cup day that club recorded a turnover of $2.3m. Many race clubs in Australia now have big prize money. In fact, 18 races in country New South Wales have prize money of $100,000 or more. This year the AJC decided that there was a need for some form of rationalisation of country racing. Of course, that is a fairly sensitive subject for country clubs and the NIMBY principle always abounds. The choice at hand is a reduction in the number of clubs, a reduction in the number of tracks, a reduction in the number of race days or a reallocation of funding.

Of course, Jim Bell has provided the impetus for the rationalisation of country racing. He has been Chairman since 1983. At that time revenue from racing was $1.2 billion. Total racing revenue is now $3.1 billion, and galloping contributes something like $2.6 billion to the coffers of the TAB. Of course, a lot of that goes back into racing.

I know that the rationalisation of country racing is a matter that concerns Jim Bell because, like me, he is a great supporter of racing in country areas. He is also a great horse owner, having owned a number of good horses including the 1979 Melbourne Cup third placegetter, Red Nose. I am sure that now he is retiring from the onerous position of Chairman he will be able to enjoy his racing more actively as an owner and a punter. He might even spend some time in New York, where he has been made a member of the New York Jockey Club—the first Australian to receive that prestigious honour.

As he is a family man with grandchildren, he may prefer to partake of the hospitality of Royal Randwick or the local racing clubs around this area, which I know he enjoys a great deal. But I am quite sure he will be able to spend more time with his grandchildren and his family. I know his daughter has been of great assistance to him during his years as Chairman, as Jim's wife died at the time he became Chairman.
I salute him for the work he has done for racing in New South Wales. I am quite sure that the Senate joins with me in saying,`Well done, Jim'. We wish you well in your retirement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government's response to the Senate Select Committee's Report on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia, which identifies the considerable progress already made in regard to the Committee's recommendations, is ready for tabling. The response has been prepared in the context of developing the National Registration Scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals which encapsulates the Committee's recommendations of a national system for registering agricultural and veterinary chemicals, a national approach to the approval of chemicals for minor crop and animal uses, and the introduction of a program to review old chemicals. A national system for registering agricultural and veterinary chemicals is proposed to commence in July 1992.

(2) The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council has under consideration the extent of industry and/or government involvement in the preparation of public release summaries. The issue of public release summaries is a complex one requiring a balance to be reached between information subject to the confidentiality provisions of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988 and the desire to provide more information to

ANSWER.PARA: the public. The Council is acting to ensure that the public receives more information about the regulation and use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and that the public release summaries on agricultural and veterinary chemical products contain information that is accurate and informative.
